reviewText:
I was a player on West server that has now quit the game entirely. I have experienced the game from 1-80, and currently have a level 80 character, as long as 60-70 for most other characters. So all of what I have to say is from experience.

Pros
Combat is engaging and skillbased.
Engine can be funny at times.


Cons
Nexon is a terrible company.
The community is full of trolls and elitists.
Economy fluctuates rapidly without rhyme or reason.
Pay2Win.
Unbalanced classes.
Early-Endgame is intimidating and unrewarding.
Progression becomes incredibly difficult.

Vindictus by definition is a Korean-made Hack 'n' Slash action game, with a choice of 8 current character classes (one upcoming) that each mostly fill a niche in the game as it stands. Storywise? The game is lacking. It's apparent that the voice acting in cutscenes are terribly synced, with zero enthusiasm whatsoever. Not to mention, it barely makes sense, it's tough to relate to any of the characters, and questing/story has devolved into a way to level up faster. As far as mechanics go, the game is amazing. Early on, the game guides you along in combat, but hits a wall in skill requirement once you begin to transition into endgame (Level 60-80). This leads to a challenging, engaging experience, as you require quite a bit of skill, and knowledge of both your character and the boss in order to succeed. Example being the solo videos out there on YouTube, which are quite impressive. Vindictus currently runs on source engine, the physics can be wonky at some times, however. With such things as clipping, or bulging polygons extending throughout the map, or a monster getting launched into space for no reason whatsoever. These can lead to much hilarity. The problems in Vindictus however, are too large for me to be able to enjoy this game anymore.

First off, let's talk about your experience from beginning to end. So you start up Vindictus. 8 characters to choose from, how exciting! Can you change their genders? Though this is something that is common in most MMOs, no. Can I change my appearance? Your options in the beginning are very limited, if you want to change up the look of your character, expect to pay $20 or more on just that. Now let's discuss the balancing of the characters, and the roles they play in Vindictus. Though this topic is very short-lived. The balancing of the game is handled very haphazardly. Currently, Hurk and Kai hold the position of godtier within the game. Where everyone else is disregarded. So if you're looking for stats, choose those two. So you've chosen your character! Time to get into the game! But wait, why don't I have any money? Well, that's because Nexon decided it would be a great idea to gut the early game by preventing gold gains from 1-25. Why? To combat botters. This is concerning however, because the earliest parts of a game are usually the most important to ensure people stay around. Surely the game will pick up right? Correct, the game does end up picking up once you are able to make some money, and have gained a general bit of knowledge about your character. Sadly, this is also when Vindictus transitions into a grindfest. Your experience at this point will consist of rushing through the storyline"

reviewText:
Vindictus is a textbook example of how Nexon operates.
They take a well designed game, tear out content, and set up a fiendish pay2play and pay2win system.
Vindictus follows this pattern to the letter.

The game itself is rather well designed. Engaging, live action, hack and slash combat is what Vindictus is all about, and the actual gameplay is pretty fun.
However, as you'll notice fairly early on, this game is absurdly grindy, and super repetitive.
Within all the areas, the difference between one level in a certain area and another level in the same area is the boss at the end...and that's it. You'll run the same path through the same map each time, fighting the same mobs each time, and doing the same things each time, until you reach the boss, which is usually marginally different from the last. (Though most times only marginally.)

Nexon has taken great care to rip out most of the gear our friends in Korea and Europe use.
In Korea and Europe, options abound for endgame gear, which greatly reduces grind.
In NA, unfortuately, the only endgame gear option is Everlasting" gear
date: which can only be obtained by finding a rare item in a raid dungeon (which you can only do 3 times per week) which has a drop rate of below 0.0000001%.\n(Subsequent patches have added other gear options

reviewText:
8k character limit :c. full vers here: http://pastebin.com/RTJn7Vyk
Before I begin, the steam version of Vindictus is the NA version of the game, which services to the NA region + Australia. There is an IP lock for a good reason. If you live elsewhere, look out for the European, Korean, Japanese or Chinese (<- no IP lock on this one!) version of the game depending on where you live. There are plenty of guides online that can help you get into any of the servers I mentioned, along with English patches.
So, I’m known as Penguin. If you use the forums, or play on the West server, you might know me +hello. I don’t usually write reviews, but after seeing negative reviews only exaggerate on the negative points, I decided to write this. For the record, I started playing Vindictus on and off since open beta in 2010. Yes, scroll up and check that release date.
PROS:Gameplay, gameplay and did I mention gameplay?
Extremely skill-based
Extensive armor customization/Fashion simulator 2015
Unique combat style for each character
Amazing graphics
Amazing soundtrack
So much free stuff from events
Game has a learning curve; it takes EFFORT to get goodCONS:RNG, RNG, and did I mention RNG?
Hourly lag
Bots
Badly optimized
Limited character customization
PVP is unbalancedNEUTRAL:Peer2peer system
Cash shop
Two ends of the community
Grinding/Farming
Game has a niche audienceGameplay:
Simply amazing. This is the main reason anyone plays Vindictus. As far as I am aware, there is no f2p mmorpg on the western market that even comes close to how fluid and enjoyable the combat system Vindictus has to offer. The game runs around a normal/smash combo system where you use left/right clicks (or j/k keys or your gamepad buttons) to control your character. Unlike your traditional mmo, there is no tab-targeting, and your quickslots are mainly for potions and consumables. I fell in love with Vindictus’ combat system 5 years ago. 5 years later, I still love it. For comparison purposes, Vindictus is like Monster Hunter or Dark Souls.

Extremely skill-based:
As discussed in the above post, Vindictus is a non-targetting action mmorpg. Raiding involves learning how to use your character’s survival mechanic to survive the attack patterns each boss has. Unlike many other action mmos on the market, a fraction of a second is enough to determine whether you survive or die to a boss. Something I heard from Junyoop, a relatively famous player and streamer of Vindictus KR (Mabinogi Heroes): ”in many mmos, if you play the class that has a shield without equipping the shield, it is impossible to survive. However in Vindictus, you can play the character with a shield (Fiona), and still do extremely well without equipping the shield”. As someone who mains Fiona, it’s true. You can play shieldless Fiona and survive solely with your invincibility-frameless roll, granted you have the skill. There are a few instances of sandbag bosses (Lakoria, Kraken head, Pantheum), but for the most part, facetanking raid bosses will most likely end with you dead.

Extensive armor customization/Fashion simulator 2015:
Need I say more? Each equipment set has an extremely unique appearance, with most equipment having three dye slots that you can customize. You can even cosplay your favorite characters from whatever game/anime/TV/movie using the armor sets and dye system available in-game [and you can acquire the look you want using ONLY in-game gold!](click here[vindictus.nexon.net] for some examples). Seriously, Vindictus can may well be fashion simulator 2015 :D.

Amazing soundtrack
‘nuff said. Especially raids. Samples: one two

RNG, RNG, and did I mention RNG?
Probably the only real legitimate concern about the game. Loot is RNG, your damage has (slight) RNG, enhancing/enchanting your gear is RNG. Update: seal shop is here, you will be able to get your level 80 weapon within a week of raiding. In addition, Purple tier regina (Lv90) gear is dirt cheap.

Badly optimized
Vindictus was developed on the Source 1 engine. As a result, the game mostly runs on one core, resulting in your modern multicore processor taking performance hits (Intel runs better than AMD for this). As far as I am aware, there are no plans on moving to the newer Source 2 engine. DevCat has tried to remedy this issue by adding multicore support for raid hosts, and the function works amazingly when it does decide to work, but the multicore function is still in beta and can be buggy.

PVP is unbalanced
Because Vindictus was intended to be a PvE game. PvP was only added because of popular demand. Devcat has made some modifications to PvP in an attempt to balance the characters, but it isn’t quite enough. It’s still fun though.

Cash shop
Cosmetics, protection items, RNG boxes (don’t buy these, ever), pets, self-revives, temporary equipment, outfitters, consumables, VIP service. Nothing game-breaking here. Vindictus is F2P, how do you think it survives? I will discuss everyone’s favorite topic of “pay2win?” at the end.

Two ends of the community
Like every other game, there are nice people, elitists/scumbags and the silent people who just enjoy the game. As of late, I haven’t seen many elitists nor attack requirement boats, which is really nice. The silent people who just play the game take the majority though.

Grinding/Farming
“This is a Korean MMO, it’s OBVIOUSLY a grindfest” …. In terms of leveling: not really, especially with how the low level content has been streamlined. Back in 2010, it took me a solid 8-10 hours to get to level 12. Now, it takes me 2 hours. Exp is no longer split between party members, and story quests give ridonkulous amounts of exp. Of course, there still exists some form of grinding, as this is an MMO, but seriously, unless you have zero tolerance for any kind of grinding, Vindictus isn’t much of a grind as you think it to be.

So, is Vindictus pay2win? My answer is a big, fat NO. ”But so many of the other reviews say that Vindictus is pay2win”. Go read the comments of those reviews. No reviewer has ever brought any evidence where players MUST pull out their wallets to advance in the game. Here are a few definitions of pay2win and how Vindictus does NOT meet most/all criterion.

Games that let you buy better gear or allow you to make better items then everyone else at a faster rate and then makes the game largely unbalanced even for people who have skill in the game without paying.
As the saying goes, a dead DPS is no DPS. You can have God-tier gear and still die to lack of skill, AND get out-dps’d by a skilled player with moderate gear.

Ability to purchase high-end gear with your wallet
Uh no? Unless you count the 2 day temporary lv sets, which are easily nothing in comparison to what you can acquire by actually playing the game. RNG boxes? Sure, they contain “high-end” gear, but I highly advise that you stay away from them. The rates on those boxes are crap for a reason.

Ability to get something/where that a non-paying player will never acquire without spending real cash
One thing. Prime outfitters. That is all, and the bonuses that come from prime outfitters have over regular outfitters (that can be obtained for free) are 200 att, 2 balance and in-town movement speed, which at end-game, is quite negligible. Otherwise, everything stat-wise a paying player can acquire is acquirable by a non-paying player.

PS: I sent in 2 tickets recently, both got answered within two business days. They were not NX related.

reviewText:
I feel it's time to redo this review since it's been a while and I've had more time to polish my idea of Vindictus. Let's jump right in.
Like I said in my previous review, Vindictus provides great combat immersion due to animations and combat mechanics. When you strike an enemy, unless it's a boss/miniboss, it's going to flinch or get knocked back. The combat feels weighted and many of your attacks feel meaningful rather than simply standing in front of a mob and pressing a few keys.
The dodge mechanic is vital to your survival and makes for a good system. Each class has a nice dodging/absorbing mechanic which allows you to keep up in the fight. This adds to the weighted feeling because it means you have the opportunity to avoid damage rather than be forced to take it just because an enemy swings in your general direction. Though not completely precise, it still works wonders for the general feeling of combat.
Animations and models are absolutely lovely. Nothing really feels stiff, every enemy has life to them. Devcat's animation studio is fantastic and I would love to see more beautiful animation like what they've provided with vindictus.
The music in Vindictus is incredible. The boss battles, the music in towns, it all feels fitting. There's not much else to say on this matter, I love the music.

Now for the reasons I can't recommend this game.

Nexon. Ohhh, Nexon. Why must you be such a terrible publisher? Nexon is one of the worst MMO publishers to date, generally ignoring their userbase and not paying attention to critical issues in their games until it's too late. Their customer support is downright impossible to work with. Pray you do not get hacked, for you will be waiting on customer service for likely months, if not years.
Boats are incredibly reliant on Peer to Peer connections, which can cause significant latency issues in a game about precision timing depending on the class. You could end up down and out before you even realize you got hit if you have bad latency. While multi-processing has improved on this, it is still incredibly buggy and may or may not function at all.
If you're not incredibly lucky, you will never get to participate in later game content. Most people require you to have at least 16k ATT/M.ATT in order to participate in the raids of Annwyn. If you're like the commonfolk, you probably will only have about 13-14k when you're able to participate in these raids. These require you to now find methods to get stronger. Which would be fine... if not for the risk of losing everything.
Let's start with the grind for better gear. On the one hand the game has lasted long enough for some good later-game gear to get cheaper. However, most of the gear you need to GET to those tough raids are... in those tough raids, incredibly rare/expensive, or require a grind that lasts for weeks. Later locations require you to run through multiple maps, sometimes back and fourth, to progress. It's similar to how it used to be, but has changed significantly. These locations are much larger and can't be navigated nearly as quickly. The main offenders of this are the Twilight Desert and Moonlight Peak.
Now let's move on to enhancements/enchantments. Enhancements allow you to gain boosts to your weapons/armor up to a certain degree. You use enhancement stones in order to do this, and enhancements can be done up to 15 times. However, you risk decreasing the enhancement, resetting it, or destroying your weapon/armor as you progress up the chain. It becomes harder and harder to upgrade each time you enhance, leading you up to a point where the odds are nowhere near in your favor. You can purchase enhancement runes to protect your item from resets/damage, but that's all it does, it is no assurance you will succeed. Not only that, you must pay real currency in order to purchase this item.
Now for enchantments. Enchantments can give your weapon/armor certain buffs based on the enchantment scroll you use. Enchantment scrolls are ranked in letter/number grades, with rank 8 currently being the highest. Higher ranked scrolls are harder to obtain and are also harder to use to enchant items. You're less likely to succeed with a rank A-8 scroll verses an F-C scroll. You can improve chances through the use of Brynn Elixirs, but only to certain degrees. The punishment for failure is a bit worse than that of enhancement due to the more likely chance of success. Your item either loses durability or is destroyed. Like enhancements, you can get enchantment runes to protect from failure. Same deal as before.
Now I could look past this if not for the awful way they handle recovery. You can now recover your equipment through the strange traveler for the low low cost of AP. Wait, did I say low low? I meant incredibly high. Level 70+ gear is going to cost you at least 20,000+ AP if you want to recover it. If you've been levelling your skills, this should be next to impossible to do outright. So now you must go back to all those daily missions/missions you didn't do too much and grind out to get your equipment back. Or you can buy AP or wait for meditation AP. None of these options are incredibly appealing.
Overall grinding is a chore, not in the least bit pleasant to do. This goes without saying for most MMOs but I feel that Vindictus has made it much worse.

So suffice to say I love the game at its core. Gameplay itself is fun. Being locked out of later missions just because I can't grind/be lucky/pay money? Not so much fun. I recommend steering clear if you have issues with severe grind/sudo-P2W" gameplay. If you can look past these issues
date: then feel free to play. I just can't recommend this game."

reviewText:
Vindictus is a relatively well-made free to play MMO with a real time combat at its core. Optional pay component assist the player in levelling and customisation of their character.

Where character design is concerned the game offers a detailed (and above average) character editor but remains restricted to a handful of pre-designed in look and combat abilities archetypes.

In principle the game is all about instanced combat. Each instance is travelled to by the party where it can attempt to complete various primary and secondary quests as its members hack their way through legions of instance specific monsters. The whole thing takes between 15 minutes to 1 hour (at least in the early stages of the game) after which you are free to move onto a next instance (as long as it has been unlocked in story progress).

Enemy AI, aside from bosses is non-existent, though boss fights are challenging and on rare occasions entertaining.
There is a story attached to this offering though it should be interpreted through Far Eastern lenses (NPCs, archetypes, conversations, events are exactly what you would expect to find in modern JRPG).

Vindictus is a mediocre game, one that lacks support and interest from its developer and publisher. Nexon is quick to ban players (even paying ones) for problems beyond their (players) control and the GMs remain unresponsive to their tickets leaving some stranded for weeks if not months at time and in some cases without a way to resolve the issues.

All in all there are better offerings available to those interested in free to play setup as such it is my recommendation to give this one a miss.

reviewText:
So you want to play Vindictus? Heres what you want to know and my personal experince/opinions.

First and foremorst, while i do reccomend this game. Be wary, dont let it consume it, dont let it get to you. My total play time doesnt come from years of play, but rather months. And while a lot of it is due to afk hours (especially getting tired and just leaving the game open while i slept) thered be alot more if it counted my playtime i had on the standalone desktop version (downloaded from the site, used whenever steam wouldnt let me log on)

PROS:

-*TRULY* a free to play game. You honestly dont have to spend a dime if you dont want to, and thats something i loved. Almost anything can be bought with gold in game.  (The only *exception* to this is the under armor, mainly for females. No, not because i want my character to run around in skimpy underwear, but because the defult underclothes will make some armors look bad. Especially shorter skirts/shorts. Now while you dont *need* this, its something that i opted to buy on both my female characters. Thankfully Nexon is nice and offers a kinda cheap deal of $13 PERMANANT Inner armor/Hair style (choose wisely))
-Really nice graphics for a free to play game. My Notebook couldnt handle the max settings, most of the time i played on lowest to push out the most fps i could get, but i have friends who can run it better, or watch videos. The game is honestly stunning, from environments to boss battles.
-Fairly well learning/difficulty curve. Easy to learn, hard to master.
-Fairly nice community, specially if you join up with a guild when you start, i made some friends that will always hold a place in my heart.
-Nexon hosts frequent events with rewards/giveaways. Allowing you to snag $ items for free.
-(Pro/Con) Easy to get into and to continue playing, lots of things to do and work towards.

CONS:

-Nexon.. Need i say more?
-FPS problems on lower-end systems, most likely caused by server inflation and patches with new content (This is one of the reasons i took a large break and then eventually quit the game. I used to not have many problems, but after Arisha came out and Nexon started handing out items like candy, my fps dropped to basically unplayable levels (15-10 or lower). If your PC is beefy enough to handle the game well, you shouldnt have a problem, but me and my notebook wept.)
-Community. Im adding this in both PROs and CONs because well, thats how people are. Ive ran into some really rude people, made my fair share of enemies, and got ripped off more then once.. But, that honestly goes for any MMO.
-Boat kicking/ATT requirement. Early on, this isnt a problem. You wont notice it and it wont bother you. Later on, when you start getting to lvl 70+ people will start tagging Attack requirements onto thier boats, kicking anyone who doesnt quailify. While i understand that certain bosses may need this due to the fact that theres a high chance youll fail if your DPS isnt good enough, Its troublesome, specially if you dont spend money/grind for hours/have help.
-GRINDING. This is the last, but probably one of the most important things. Unless you get help, or know how to play the market really well, youre going to have to grind for your items. This kinda goes hand and hand with the boat kicking. Boss drops sell for ALOT of gold, but are extremely rare and RNG, and thats hard to grind for if youre getting kicked all the time. Just be wary about it, find good friends, and enjoy the game.

I leave it up to you if you want to play the game or not, i HIGHLY reccomend you at least download and try the game out. Dont be discouraged by the CONs, its ultimately up to you wether or not you enjoy the game. Just when you play follow this 3 golden rules.

1. BE FRIENDLY AND FAIR
2. JOIN A GUILD AS SOON AS YOU CAN/MAKE FRIENDS
3. MOST IMPORTANTLY.. JUST HAVE FUN

(P.s. You may notice the striking numbers of downvotes and negitive replies, while there is a bit of truth in all of them, the games not going to get better without new people coming into the game. With more and more people leaving or getting turned away by the bad reviews, the game is just going to become worse.. Its slowly dying. Only you can fix it, or at least try to help.)

reviewText:
RNG.

In a simple definition, it's what completely controls our lives.

Sure, you may have had your buddy boost you levels 1-90 for free. That's really nice. Maybe you got in some of those double xp weekends too and you got your level easily. That's great, levels are great.

But it comes at a price.
All gear comes at a price. You may think I mean crafting, but no. Crafting is the easy part.

The real price of playing this game is your entire life. The amount of time it takes you to pray to RNG GOD for him to bless you with enough drops to afford your best 90 gear is the same amount of time it takes the average human born, to die.
You will die playing this game. This game will ♥♥♥♥ you until you are sucked dry of your emotions and you become an endless farming machine, you will become a slave to NEXON and their NX prices, praying to get money to buy enchanting runes so you don't break your gear while crafting. You will spend the same amount of time getting to max level, adding +1000 dmg to your weapon by enhancing it. Did I mention, if your RNG fails you have to start all over? You do.
I ♥♥♥♥ing hate this game but it keeps calling me back for more. I lay in bed and I can't sleep. My daily raids that I can run twice a day call out to me, begging me to run them, begging me to crawl endless dungeons in hope for shining gold, an enchant scroll, a piece of loot that I can finally feel good about the many years it will take to buy that endgame gear.
I've sacrificed my friends and drank various blood potions to be blessed with good luck, nothing has worked. I've begged ferghus to Welcome me to the forge" dozens of times. All I can do with the rest of my life is pray to God I will make some ♥♥♥♥ing money.

The combat is pretty fun

reviewText:
Intro
Vindictus is a Free-to-Play game focused on real-time interactive combat. The gameplay is fast-paced with emphasis on timing and reactions compared to traditional MMO's. The developers, devCAT, accomplished this by making it dungeon based with party limits. It's a game that relies on peer-2-peer for hosting purposes.

Environments
+ Different environments
+ Sections are randomized

Every chapter has a different theme with several maps. Sections of the levels are randomized to prevent the game from being too repetitive. Variety of traps can be discovered in many of the levels.

You end up grinding, if  you don't finish enough quests or simply want to power level the fastest way possible. Grinding is not bad until you hit level 43~ where hidden is. Hidden is the most tempting grind spot in the game for exp and will result in you neglecting some side-quests in favor of it.

Characters (Classes)
+ Unique playstyles

The classes stick out alot as a result of unique weapons,skill sets, and stats. Playing as for example Kai will feel dramatically different from a evie even if they both use range attacks and are not as complex as the other heros. You will find yourself trying out all of them because they got alot of varation to offer you.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=269462338

Equipment/Loot
Equipment is not to hard to get to be useful until you get level 59+ where it becomes more of a challenge. That being said since the big payoffs are the daily raids its worth it just to login to play against epic bosses and have a lottery ticket chance at the nice items possible to drop from them.

Pay to win or not?
Now the question you may have is. Is it free to play or pay to win? Really I would be sort of lieing if I said that money didn't give you ridiclous advantages over others. It is far easier to upgrade your equipment and get stronger gear. As a free to play model it ranks average seeing as how gameplay wise it mostly just benefits people who party with them but at same token this game is mostly geared towards PvE so its not really that much of a concern when the heavy hitters are on your side 99% of the time.

reviewText:
I was a player on West server that has now quit the game entirely. I have experienced the game from 1-80, and currently have a level 80 character, as long as 60-70 for most other characters. So all of what I have to say is from experience.

Pros
Combat is engaging and skillbased.
Engine can be funny at times.

Cons
Nexon is a terrible company.
The community is full of trolls and elitists.
Economy fluctuates rapidly without rhyme or reason.
Pay2Win
Unbalanced classes.
Early-Endgame is intimidating and unrewarding.
Progression becomes incredibly difficult.

Vindictus by definition is a Korean-made Hack 'n' Slash action game, with a choice of 8 current character classes (one upcoming) that each mostly fill a niche in the game as it stands. Storywise? The game is lacking. It's apparent that the voice acting in cutscenes are terribly synced, with zero enthusiasm whatsoever. Not to mention, it barely makes sense, it's tough to relate to any of the characters, and questing/story has devolved into a way to level up faster. As far as mechanics go, the game is amazing. Early on, the game guides you along in combat, but hits a wall in skill requirement once you begin to transition into endgame (Level 60-80). This leads to a challenging, engaging experience, as you require quite a bit of skill, and knowledge of both your character and the boss in order to succeed. Example being the solo videos out there on YouTube, which are quite impressive. Vindictus currently runs on source engine, the physics can be wonky at some times, however. With such things as clipping, or bulging polygons extending throughout the map, or a monster getting launched into space for no reason whatsoever. These can lead to much hilarity. The problems in Vindictus however, are too large for me to be able to enjoy this game anymore.

First off, let's talk about your experience from beginning to end. So you start up Vindictus. 8 characters to choose from, how exciting! Can you change their genders? Though this is something that is common in most MMOs, no. Can I change my appearance? Your options in the beginning are very limited, if you want to change up the look of your character, expect to pay $20 or more on just that. Now let's discuss the balancing of the characters, and the roles they play in Vindictus. Though this topic is very short-lived. The balancing of the game is handled very haphazardly. Currently, Hurk and Kai hold the position of godtier within the game. Where everyone else is disregarded. So if you're looking for stats, choose those two. So you've chosen your character! Time to get into the game! But wait, why don't I have any money? Well, that's because Nexon decided it would be a great idea to gut the early game by preventing gold gains from 1-25. Why? To combat botters. This is concerning however, because the earliest parts of a game are usually the most important to ensure people stay around. Surely the game will pick up right? Correct, the game does end up picking up once you are able to make some money, and have gained a general bit of knowledge about your character. Sadly, this is also when Vindictus transitions into a grindfest. Your experience at this point will consist of rushing through the storyline"

reviewText:
When it comes to ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes, it's really damn hard to find an actually decent one. Thankfully, Vindictus is one of the few that may be worth playing.
Pros:
-A lot of action and a pretty decent amount of customization.
-Nice looking armors, weapons, and characters.
-Fun and (sometimes) challenging enemies.
-Pretty fluid and fast-paced combat.
-Moderately decent storyline (In comparison to other MMOs)
Cons:
-A decent amount of the REALLY good items you need to buy with actual money, which kind of sucks.
-Can occasionally be repetitive or boring at times depending on where you are in levels/story.

Personally, I think this is one of the few moderately enjoyable MMOs I've played. If you want something that's more fast-paced and has a great amount of action compared to the usual MMO, this is the game for you.
If you've checked the game out and don't like it, but still want a fast-paced action MMO, another game I can point you toward is Warframe, though that has some major differences in comparison to Vindictus.

Before I really go into the review, I must admit I had a lot of fun playing this game. It's very unique and I've yet to see another MMO come close to the smooth combat system that Vindictus has. The game, much like any other popular MMO's, is a drug and you have this tendency to keep playing (which still happens to me sadly). However, with that said, the other aspects of this game is atrocious. The easiest way to get into things would be a pro-con chart.

Pro
Unique combat gameplay that requires timing and skill to deal the most damage (Dark Souls-esque but at 2x speed)
Mechanics of the game work relatively well (Skill paths, different attacks, special attacks)
Unique set of characters, each with their own play style and difficulty
Full man party raids against huge bosses
Wide variety of bosses, missions, etc.
As of recent update, easier to get rare" drops from bosses to craft higher level items (seal shop

reviewText:
TL:DR - Introducing Vindictus: Brought to you by Nexon. A company that lures players with FREE to play games
but eventually you'll give into temptation and spend a ton of money -cough Pay2win-
NOT for fun. If you want to have fun, I suggest you play something else and stay away from NEXON.

First we have to pick a class/character to start, 9/10 players would ignore the big black guy.
Let's pick a girl, while we're at it, why not make her look attractive and sexy. (Definitely not trying to hit on guys online)

Let's start with character customization, you pay for your hair and underwears, Deal with it.
10/10 would enlarge boobs to maximum. The more pixels you have, the better.

Let's play the game now, level 1 to level 40. Basic training and learning the foundation of your character's
move sets and skills, do the same maps over and over again and you finally do some quest to get transformation.
(You're very likely to play by yourself until level 60)

Now level 40-60, you've learnt how to kill mobs in a few clicks of the mouse and bosses are re-models of every
single mob you see and they're either bigger or have different colours.

The real challenge lies in raiding, like any MMORPG would lead you to.             I LIED.

The real challenge is within the community.
Most of you would quit before level 30 realizing how boring grinding can be. Otherwise, allow yourself to be
introduced to the community, visit channel 1 for all the emotional dramas.

Embrace yourself to:
Poverty - buy some gold, buy some nx, empty your wallet and credit card, what is life? vindi is life.
Bragging - 400 titles! such is life, +15 level 80 items, majestic as osama bin laden. Bombing raid bosses with dem DEEPS.
Envy - What OP players have is what you want, what you want is what leads you to poverty.
Autism - Learn to deal with people that are autistic, you cannot learn from anywhere else better.
Cancer - What you get if you can't deal with autism.
Harrassment - Bad at something? Said something wrong? Did nothing? You get it no matter what you do.
Depression - What you get when you finished the game and realized how much time and money you've spent.
Anger - Proudly brought to you by Nexon, sponsored by pay2win players and trolls.

Back to raids, attack requirement boats, isolated from raid parties, no invites? Congraulations you have hit the
dead end of Vindictus.

At this point, it's time to pluck your money out of your wallet and shove it up Nexon's butt hole.

-Buy some AP
-Buy some gachapon boxes
-Buy some runes to enhance and enchant
-Buy some gold while you're at it, everyone knows you're poor

Level 60-85, you grind between repetitive dungeons and raid bosses in order to gear up and do new
contents. At this point, you should be asking yourself, what's the meaning of all this grind?

We all have fun in the games we play, we all want the strongest items in game and want to be known
for achieving and looking fabulous. If you don't think you've had enough of that, enjoy wasting more
time and money refining your character that'll eventually make yourself ask the same question above.

Otherwise congraulations, you've finished the game. Regrets... too late. Literally a dungeon's name that warned you
before Level 60 contents where you may resort to spending money.

10/10 recommending 12-16 year old players, autistic rustled jimmies and cancerous trolls.

reviewText:
PLEASE READ MY ENTIRE POST. THERE ARE PARTS OF THIS GAME THAT I DO RECOMMEND


This game used to be great. Now its a unoptimized, lagging, 90% P2W fest.

Wind the clock back a few years (to a time before it was on Steam) This game was amazing and I put easily another 200 hours into the game in addition to the hours shown on Steam.

Take Dark Souls combat, speed it up by 10x and give it more depth. Add some of the most badass music, awesome enemies, and the most flashy/beautiful combat animations and graphics and you had Vindictus at its peak.
Heck it was just barely grindy, it had awesome combat, every fight felt awesome, you looked awesome, you felt awesome.

In fact, to this day/time I've posted this review, I still have yet to find an MMO with combat as engaging, dynamic and as action packed as Vindictus.

Tera? Blade and Soul? PFFFT, not even close to the speed and fluidity of Vindictus.

But now to the present. Vindictus has gone down hill, and Nexons only fked up it further with their greedy ♥♥♥ cashgrabbing.

First off, as I've said before, the game lags like ♥♥♥♥ now for larger raids (it used to be so much more fluid). Only the smaller runs retain most of the fluidity.
I have 55.80Mbps download speed, and 9.85Mbps upload speed with 12MS ping.
I'm also running a pretty high end gaming setup, over $1k easily

And this game is still choppy as hell on LOW-MED settings. Not matter how badass your combat is if your frames are ♥♥♥♥ and everything is teleporting/choppy as fk the game will still feel like ♥♥♥♥.

Why are they stupidly low? So Nexon can sell you items that can protect" your items from being destroyed when you fail a high level enhance. AND THEY ARE ONLY 1 TIME USES

reviewText:
I've played this game since CBT and it's been awesome. It is a very fast paced action oriented MMO. To be honest, I didn't pay much attention to the story as I played it like Monster Hunter. I enjoyed this game even without the story. The beginning can be very dull but it gets better later on. Having friends and guild members to mess around with in instances and raids definitely makes a difference. There won't be much players on lower level instances for the most part unless there's going to be a new character released. Expect to grind for materials for armor unless you have the cash to buy it.

Disclaimer: I haven't played the game too much after season 2 arrived

Pros:
- Unique and fun Characters
- Character skills are awesome
- Each Character has a choice between two weapon types
- Amazing visuals
- Combat is fluid and fast
- Very challenging (soloing instances, raids etc)
- There's a storyline
- Perverted camera at the end of each instance
- No more token system
- Spin to win (go play spear Lann, though you probably will get kicked from raids)

Cons:
- Gender locked (for those who have problems with this)
- Lag/DC out of an instance (I remember the servers lagged pretty hard and everyone was trying to crash it because it wasn't getting restarted)
- Grind fest
- Pay to win (can buy revives and instant potions to your advantage)
- Enhancing/Enchanting weapons may require you to spend real cash (not required though as it just increase the chances of success)
- You have to go through the cut scene on the boat every time :/
- Can't hide megaphone chat

If none of the cons bother you, check it out its an amazing game.

reviewText: Great gameplay trapped inside a horrible game.  If you value gameplay, then play it since it is very good, but everything else about the game is complete ♥♥♥♥.  If your starting out get ready to have a ♥♥♥♥ ton of fun till the mid 20s then get ready to wait for the chance to ever group within any else till 60s for the raids, as they community is not very active between those two spots.  If you can make it to 60 get ready to die a lot and do nothing in the raids till you get decent equipment from doing them a lot.  But if you can make it up there and get decent equipment then the game becames a ♥♥♥♥ ton of fun as the raid bosses are a lot of fun with the gameplay and are the best part of the game.  Having played since the orginal NA launch and seen the game evolve I can say that if you make it up there and beat all of the raid bosses and get good equipment, get ready to wait several monthes for them to add anything new. reviewText:
The game was pretty awesome during the first several years since (open/closed) beta. However, now the game is obviously suffering from many afflictions that a MMO goes through going past it's prime.

Events are no longer entertaining or worth doing, events have been degraded to the point where it's either free consumables from cash shop, increased EXP/AP/Raid Counts etc, or cash shop sales.
Typical blatant cash grabs by Nexon in the form of in-game pets or vanity sets, seriously $30 for vanity set?
Being able to run the later raids especially in Season 2 requires excellent gear, most of which will be forever out of a large majority of player's reach, unless you buy gold...
The inflation in this game is pretty bad but maybe not as ridiculous as other MMOs but new player's have almost no chance.
Population decline.
The actual gameplay revolving around 3rd person camera is actually quite good, it is very reminiscent and similar to how Ninja Gaiden operates. Overall a MMO that had great potential but is marred by Nexon's incompetence and/or greed in addition to the inevitable degenerative effects of human nature...
voteText: 78 of 106 people (74%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Product received for free

It's fun, but in the long run you will be crippled if you're unwilling to spend money

The combat system is honestly one of the best I've played for an MMO, even beating out melee oriented action games of the singleplayer variety. The characters have unique playstyles, stylish moves and a great degree of combat is based on player skill. Some of the boss battles are insanely fun, and the fights are engaging so you dont feel like you're just stabbing a giants toe until he keels over. One character can even use his strength to stop certain boss attacks mid-swing and enter a clash of strength if you can time it correctly. It feels pretty badass to save a party member from a potentially fatal blow and in the process hold the boss down for your other teammates to kick his ♥♥♥♥ in

Unfortunately these attributes are hampered by the fact that end game content is severely walled off. Most of the end game raid partys which are level 80-90 will require a high amount of ATT stat (which is what attack damage is based on), to the point where if you dont upgrade your weapons, its unlikely you will break that ceiling. Although this sounds normal the problem lies here

Upgrading your gear is EXTREMELY RNG dependant. The blacksmith may weaken your items durability and reset all enhancements hes previously done on it back to 0, or just outright destroy it at higher ranks. The magician can enchant your item with special qualities, but once again this is RNG dependant and can damage your gear if it fails.
But of course there is a way to prevent these outcomes: $$MONEY$$

If you want any realistic chance of upgrading your rare and difficult to obtain weapon to a respectable level, you will NEED either cash shop items or a large amount of resources and attempts. Dont think for a second that other people dont use these items either, pretty much everyone you see will have at least +8 weapons on high level raids. You CAN get these items from events, but they are one use only and quite rare. They aren't guaranteed successes either, they just protect your weapon from getting damaged, so you could stockpile 4 of them from events and level milestones only to reach enhancement level 7.

The game would be a 9/10 for me if it wasnt so dependant on RNG to make progress late game. You can try it up to around level 70, before the RNG kicks in too hard, but after that I wouldn't recommend it. But if you like to gamble or have a plenty of cash on hand, go for it.

if you think I'm overblowing the whole RNG thing, you can check the wiki for the RNG tables yourself : http://vindictus.gamepedia.com/Item_Enhancement  But keep in mind, the upgrades are not equally spread, so going from +2 to +3 doesnt have anywhere near the same effect as going from +6 to +7

TL:DR End game is a slot machine for necessary gear upgrades, and the community is on life support since black desert came out

reviewText:
3000h+ edit \o/

Very well-done Korean Hack n Slash MMO-RPG Co-op game. I've been playing since Closed Beta, there are ups and down such as usual lags that most of Free-to-Play games tend to have, games combat area is hosted by a player rather then Vindictus server, so connection between you and the host tend to be very important. Just to note, when they have outfits on sale for limited time only, they mean it, those things never comes back on sale except on very rare cases. (real money outfits. If its rune of some sort, high chance it will be back later on but not often.)

To answer if this game is Pay To Win, I would rather say this game is more of Luck to Win. There are so many RGN (Random Generated Number?) things are there, such as
95% of raid drops, which you kinda want a good drop for money if you do not want to farm (personally I dont think Vindictus is a farming game, its a bit hard to 'farm' and time consuming compare to other mmo) However this doesnt really happen often that sometime you wont even really get anything thats worth a money untill couple month later of running every daily raids.
Above RNG drop rate is to change with new sealshop update so anyone who bother to farm raids for a month can have full geared 80 set.
Enhancing (Success rate 100% -> 75% -> etc etc decrease down to 40%)
Enchanting (Depends on Ranks, and your input. Almost everything thats useful enchants have 40~50% rate of success and it can blow off your equipments when not used with rune)
I would say Enchancing and Enchanting is the number one reason why people come to quit this game.
Infusion (Either gives you crappy ♥♥♥ stat or even negative stat)
Ofcourse, all of above doesnt matter (enhancing/enchanting/Infusion) as much if you are not one of those 'elite' people. (..I kinda am)

Characters have their own name(other then the one that you name. People call out the characters given name to defind their 'Class'), and are gender locked. I didnt really mind about Gender-locked system since I was never really bothered by 'I really wish I could play as a female/male character' All 8 Character have their personal weapons that does have very different characteristic and I suggest you try other 'class' if you do not like the one you've chosen.
So far in order of release -
Lann(M) - Dual Sword (Shares with Vella)/Dual Spear
Fiona(F) - Hammer/Sword + Small Shield/Large Shield (Large shield is practically useless)
Evie(F) - Staff / Scythe
Karok(M) - Pillar/Blaster
Kai(M) - Bow/Crossgun
Vella(F) - Dual Sword (Weapon is Shared with Lann)/Dual Chain
Hurk(M) - Great Sword
Lynn(F) - Battle Glaive

Combat system is very well done I always comes back to Vindictus due to its unique combat system thats rarely found in any other MMO RPG. Very awesome effects but carries counter side. Sometimes raid becomes messive 'Wherethefkistheboss' situation when the boss happened to be a human character size. There is an option to not show other players effect but human size monsters are still not visible when its inbetween 5,6 characters.)
Because you have to time and counter/block enemy attack when required, its hard to do so with bad connection. Since servers are not provided except in 24men raids, connection between you and the host tend to be reallllllllly important. You will NOT be able to move when its a crucial movement, and attack if you are running with someone thats not able to host or in long distant area from you.

Story, you will love the story compare to other mmos if you are interested in reading them. There are two story, Season One, and Season Two. Its easily explained like a quest in any MMO, where main character is asked to take A or B route. So those who take Season 1 would be considered as they have taken A route when those who take on Season 2 would be considered as they have taken B route. Which one is better? Personally I will say Season One. I just couldnt come to like of Season Two. Season One however is very very well done in my opinion, I suggest everyone to read them.

There will be couple areas player come to be bored for the new players and quits mostly in that area which is around level 25 ~ 35 esh. However real game starts over level 60+, I suggest anyone that plays to take time and play up to 60 where they can start the raids.

You like dress-up games? because Vindictus do a good job of it. Yea sure they do have couple outfits you have to buy in real money to enjoy your new look, but there are only maybe 3-4 outfits thats not limited time only and all of them arnt really customizable compare to the ones that you can get from in-game. They do have stats attached to them however they arnt so game changing, limited outfits does have higher stats, but personally I dont see much difference, it helps for lower ATT users to join higher req dungeons which is set by another player. (Limited time only outfits have 500+ ATT/MATT increase)
Games town really have nothing to see if you are into looking for every single details. the very first town we incounter is the most populated place and people tend to hang around there, making new friends, untill they find a guild that is active and have their 'own' channel.

Community is.. bad..? Im not sure honostly, since I've found my 'buddies' shortly after started playing this game. I did play around in Vindictus offcial community forum as Seanna, translating Kr stuff. But I got busy and stopped translating things. When sometime I visit the forum, it kinda shows that they arnt taking care of their forum that much. As long as you find group that you like, you probably wont really care about the rest of community.

reviewText:
This game breaks my heart. It has the best fighting system in any free to play game i have ever seen. It is faster, more simple, more intuitive, and requires much more skill on the player's part.There are very few hot-bar skills. For the most part, you control every step, hit, and dodge. And there is an impact every time you hit something combined with realistic blood splotches, very rewarding. Also, there is a fighting style for anyone.

but... To unlock the full potential of your character, you have to grind to 52 just to use all your skills. From there, you probably need to reach level cap and grind for many days more to rank these skills up to the point where you can fight effectively (i.e. Battle Respiration and Stamina Mastery. If you are a melee character and you dont have these maxed, you will have some trouble keeping up with certain bosses).

But even when you have maxed all of your skills and can use your character effectively, you will be hard-pressed to get into a raid party simply because you might not have the stats necessary. So how do you get stats? You get it with very expensive and rare gear. This gear is simply unobtainable to casual players who dont want to spend money. Nexon wants their money...

The game does have a saving grace, however, and this is why I love it. There are some great guilds out there that are willing to help out new players with leveling, gearing, money earning, and enjoying the game. Many powerful guilds will be willing to take under-geard folks into end-game raids for chances at loot and practice. Any active guild will, to some degree, fulfill most of Nexon's shortcomings and make the game fun (I say most" because there are problems that NOBODY can fix like server issues).

If you are interested in playing
date: find a guild and be active in it. They will treat you well and you will have a good time.\n(Good Guilds: Colossus/Wanton

reviewText:
pros:
-fast paced combat
-characters all feel fresh and unique
-Free to play
-Fairly enjoyable leveling process
-Decent story

cons
-cash shop becoming more pay to win with stats on items
-nexon has terrible customer service
-grind grind grind
-slow content updates, takes about 4-6 months a update
-enhancing system is the worst
-enchanting or enhancing requires money or you get lucky and risked blowing up items and destroying you characters equipment
-servers are slow and constantly need fixes
-Nexon customer service is awful. They do not have a line you can call and tickets can take 4+ months to get answered. I have had a ticket filed in june and not get answered till decenber.

Overall I would not recomend this game due to the fact it will turn many people off once they hit the wall of end game grind and begin to understand how the cash shop effects the overall effectiveness of your character. But for the few people that are used to grinding and when I say grinding I mean doing the same content for months on end then this game will be good for you. I personally enjoyed this game when it was alive but now it has been slowly falling off and many of the players I use to play with and know are no longer playing this game.

Free to play so in the end never hurts to play it and see for yourself.

UPDATE: Just wanted to give an update if the game has changed at all and sadly it has not. Content still comes at a snails pace and NA servers are still a mess. The gameplay is still the main core of the game and makes it playable but the cons still weigh this title down. The main problem is how Nexon does not treat this game well, maintain, or improve it.

Still does not hurt to try. Best way to find out if this game is for you is to try. Free so as long as you don't spen in the cash shop the game will cost you nothing and no harm in trying a free game.

reviewText: I honestly am surprised I haven't made a review yet for this game considing how much I've played this. After getting past the boring first levels, you jump into a game of wonders filled with multiple fun events and fun bosses with the addition of a funny/intense story. I've never been in love with an MMO this much, and it was the first I've ever played. Honestly, many people hate on it and I guess I can see why, but that shouldn't stop you from trying the game. I really only have a few steam friends that have actually played the game for more than a few hours and would love to help any newcomers when available. If you do try the game, I recommend that you join the west server regardless of your area due to the fact that east server has less people and is dead for the most part (I even heard that they get less events). One of the negatives of the game I would have to say is that the game can have issues, moreso with the steam version, but if it becomes an issue using the non-steam version in the game files can be a better choice. Either way, I encourage anyone to try it out and my 1,000+ hours don't lie at all when I say I'm addicted.

reviewText: The only MMO experience that I've actually enjoyed. (Dev's note: Look to this game for ideas for your MMO. Vindictus actually has characters and narrative with a little substance rather than a sequence of generic fedex quests. The UI is also brilliant. Game mechanics that actually get you into the fight rather than spamming macro keys.  That being said Vindictus does fall flat in a few areas. It would be far more immersive if NPC dialogue was voice acted. More/better ambient sounds wouldn't go astray either. My biggest gripe though is that the F2P micro-transactions really aren't that micro... $30 for increased inventory space? Really?  That's more than I purchase most Steam titles for.  I would be more likely to make purchases if it seemed like better value but you could easily spend a tonne of money in this game for really minor customizations. Over all though I highly recommend this to anyone new to MMOs, or to anyone who finds traditional MMOs too generic and hollow.

reviewText:
For the positives of the game:
-Fun to play if you like hack and slash.
-Great graphics.
-Somewhat decent storyline.

For the negatives of the game:
-Nexon game, so expect F2P = P2W
-Really unstable server, game goes down a lot when you don't need it to.
-You really need to bring friends into this game to make it enjoyable. Without friends, you're going to be going in empty for pretty much many of your dungeon runs.
-Mediocre customer service/PR
-Events are more of people sitting around doing nothing for ~2 hours.
-Events ingame are more often just as unstable as the game itself (An event advertised at 7PM PST will most likely happen around 9PM PST)

Overall, the negatives of the game really outweigh the positives of the game. But what can you expect? It's Nexon. It's a decent game to play, but if you really want to find an RPG (And I use this term very loosely for Vindictus), you're better off finding another game. I wouldn't really recommend this game to any of my friends because of the negatives of this game and the company that runs it.

Edit: I will add to this, since I still do not recommend it. Vindictus is pretty much a dead game. There is little to no interaction in the game at all from other players. The only time I ever see more than one person online is either in the first 3 channels, or when an event happens. And even then, people do not interact with each other, and they go to do their own thing. The game interaction is dead, and the game itself is dead. If you want to find a game that still mimics Monster Hunter, just play Monster Hunter, this game is just a Pay to Win version of Monster Hunter.

reviewText:
One of the forerunners of action based MMO, and it's still going strong with new updates coming up. If you are looking for some good solid hack and slash MMO instead of the normal click and wait ones, then this is your game. The graphics and physics of the game are awesome, and quest/storyline is well written and engaging. The combat system is innovative and continues to entertain players with new contents.

The few downsides are mostly ignorable, but game does experience constant glitches and errors from update to update. Connection is troublesome as it depends on the group leader to be the host (thus the rest of the party could lag to death, speically if you fail to dodge boss attackes on time). Personally I dislike the price of the cash items in game...despite mostly cosmetic in nature, i think some utility items such as name change coupons are too overpriced.

Despite the love-hate relationship, overall, Vindictus is a solid game well made.

reviewText:
Welcome to the world of Nexon, where every aspect of a game is pay2win.
Before I get into the negative points, I wanna say a couple words about the good stuff:

-Extremely dynamic and responsive hack and slash combat system : This is not a tab-targetting/single unit combat system. It's very unique and it's very skill-based. A fraction of a second can be the deciding factor between life and death.
-Awesome physics/graphics/particles/effects/etc. : Visually appealing. That's pretty much all I have to say.
- Great free2play from lvl 1 to 70. Then from 70-90 its another story.

Now the bad part....

-Pay2win. Did I mention pay2win? Yea pay2win by the way: Anything ranging from EXP boosts to AP boosts (This is required to lvl up Skills) to increasing enchantment success.
- Bad servers : Unstable at most times but still manageable
- A lot of unfixed bugs/crashes : It gets frustrating. Most of these are reported but it seems Nexon doesn't fel like fixing them.

It's a great game. Great potential.... but Nexon. I feel invested in my character and the combat system is just too great for me not to play. I just get tempted a bit too much by the p2win aspect.

All in all, it's worth to play for the first 70ish levels, then it becomes a grindfest for rare loot and the p2win aspect comes into play. Play at your own risk. Very addicting if you're the type of guy with some spare change.

I played this game on EAST server for few hundered hrs since 2012. (been quitting and returning). So I've seen how this game was, has been going and how it is now.

While I like the non target battles and exciting background music and all, this game is NOT NEWBIE FRIENDLY AT ALL.
Like most other rpg games, everything starts from max lvl (90)." But way to get there from scratch is total nightmare.
DO NOT START unless u have a friend who is already playing this game that can support you otherwise you'll have to cover it with insane grinding.

Not many people playing the early stages so if you start fresh you'll mostly play solo or need to get help from higher level players.

Not much chance to earn golds before level 60 and equipment inflation price starts from lvl 70 so hopefully you get lucky loots in between and earn some 'enchant scrolls' which can get you few million golds to cover the equipment prices.

For level 70+ dungeons you'll need to enhance/enchant your equipments but both processes are heavily dependant on random chances (can destroy your equipments if you fail). If you don't want to destory ur items
date:

lvl 80 equipments are so expensive (10~20million golds PER PIECE / 1 weapon + 5 armors) that people try to skip that and get lvl 90 equipments which are cheaper; which means you'll have to risk enhancing/enchanting your lvl70 gear even more (and possilbly destroy) to advance to higher lvl dungeons or keep grinding the same dungeon over and over for lvl 70-90 section.

reviewText:
The combat and gameplay are freaking amazing.
You even have to time your potion drinking in order to get the full benefit of the potion.
When you get hit, it's your fault, everything is dodgable for every character. (although it is definitely harder for some classes)
Or it's because of lag...

Before it was on steam, I probably had 800+ hours.
I had 5 classes at level 70.

This game inspired me to study to make my own game.
Because I have yet to find anything close to the gameplay.
The closes thing so far was the Dark Souls series, but it's combat is relatively slow compared to Vindictus.

I don't recommend this game because of the community you have to endure to play it.
So many trolls and elitists.
You HAVE to sell things on the forums to make money to get better gear.
And you NEED better gear in order to get into better raids that drop better items.
It becomes very pay2win in the end game.
The servers suck. So when your party leader disconnects from a daily raid, it can ruin your entire run for that day.
And it happens often.

But if you are into game design and you like cool mechanics on bosses you should definitely check out some of them.
Here's a list I recommend if you choose to try the game.
Area > Dungeon > Boss
-Ruins of Sanctity > Hidden > Giant Spider
-Ainle > Shadowed by Darkness > The Blood Lord
-Hoarfrost Depths > Irukul > Irukul
-Fomorian Base > The Giant > Titan
-Sewers > The Dark, Dank Sewers > Thor
-Ortel Castle > Alghan the Golem > Alghan
-Ortel Castle > The Central Garden > Ingkells
-Catacombes > Avatar of Destruction > Glas Ghaibhleann
-Albey > Betrayal > Controlled Black Hammer
-Albey > The Evil One > Lionotus
-Albey > Colru the Golem > Colru (easily one of the coolest fights if no trolls are on your team. 8-man raid gets split up into 4 groups of 2 to fight 4 parts of Colru, it's pretty awesome)
-Heide > Earthborn Seal > Siglint
-Heide > Fostborn Seal > Beokros
-Heide > Timeless Rage > Elchulus
Although all the Heide dragons have basically the same movesets and different skins, they each have their own different mechanics you need to work around to defeat them.

And there's the Kraken, similar to Colru, but the team gets split up into 5 group, Not really split up physically, but everyone has their own Kraken limb to concentrate on, or the whole ship gets crushed and everyone dies. Which is pretty neat.

reviewText: It's a free MMO with the visceral hack and slash combat system of a paid one.  The game is a lot more skill based than it is stat based, meaning you HAVE to dodge attacks, time yours well and not stand there like a ♥♥♥♥♥ soaking up damage like in WoW.  This MMO is anything but traditional, in both good and bad respects, the good being the aforementioned combat and the fact that you don't have to sink hours a day into the game to get stuff done.  The downside is, there's no huge world to explore, just a small hub you return to in order to recieve and complete quests.  The combat is done entirely instance-based, and much of those instances need to be repeated, so repetition WILL be there.  Finally, most machines will struggle over the ham-fisted optimisation and some players who prefer to solo their MMOs won't get very far without rolling with a party, so I highly reccomend you go into this with friends.  It's a good game though, and you've got nothing to lose in trying it.

reviewText:
As a person who frantically searched for a good hack and slash MMO I thought I had finally found a slice of heaven in Vindictus. It's very interactive and requires you to be attentive and think on your feet in fights, lest your enemies best you. Additionally, the character design and physics engine are quite unique for a free-to-play game.

Unfortunately, there are several things keeping Vindictus from being a good MMO; the pay-to-win feature being in first place. To elaborate a bit, the first thing that comes to my mind is the 'inner armor' feature, where your character can be fitted with customizable undergarments that is worn under the armor. Your character is fitted with defult inner armor, but the nicest way to move on with this review, is to state that if you don't want to look like an idiot, you must purchase nexon points to buy new armor to look less foolish in the armors you pick up in the game. Inner armor is only the beginning, players can purchase 'temporary armor' which allows for any level player to rent a set of high-level armor for about 7 days, for nearly a real dollar each day, as well as items that can selected in a random lottery (purchaseable of course!) that are not necessarily usable by your character, but that also can not be sold in the in-game trading post. Finally for this topic, there are also 'bound' items; which are items that get locked to your character and make them unsellable in the marketplace or trading post. To unbind these, you must then purchase from the game store, potion stacks that may or may not have enough per stack, to unbind your item and make it sellable.  Which brings me to my next problem with Vindictus: ingame money system.

The ingame money system in this game is absolutely in shambles. There does not seem to be any rhyme, reason or hierarchy for items which may be put up for sale. I have, on more than one occassion, found something as simple as cloth for sale for around 1k gold, and something that's difficult to pick up or find, on sale for 400 gold. If I check the market the next day, the cloth may have gone down to 200 gold, and the rarer item could inflate up to 3k in gold. It doesn't seem Nexon is setting any rules for these items to be sold at a minimum or maximum price, resulting in player prices that are unheard of, be they high or low. This means when you get to higher levels, paying for armor past level 54 is nearly impossible as armor inflates from around 24k per piece to 1-2 million quite quickly and weapons are even higher in price. The burden becomes real when you realize you're exchanging around 70k in gold for repairs and health potions. Not to mention that the pay rate between NPC sale rates and user marketplace rates have a very significant gap.

Making money is out of the question for your first 15-20 levels; and that is no exaggeration. Nexon actually released a patch that prevented players below a certain level from gaining monetary rewards in dungeons, and to impress upon this, I would like to add that Vindictus is completely instanced; there are no open world opportunities. Now you may pick items up in a dungeon that could sell for money, but nothing noteable enough to allow you to upgrade things such as armor or weapons. Making money in later dungeons is a bit easier, but often requires quite a bit of trickery or repeat trips, which can ocassionally be fun I admit, but becomes cumbersome after the first few times you attempt it. Be that as it may, it's still very difficult to save enough money for crafting or purchasing new armor or weapons as you get higher in level, which makes doing dungeons, and more importantly raids, where the majority of your money comes from at higher levels, very difficult. In some cases, after completing a raid a certain amount of times, you completely stop gaining money from it.

Speaking to dungeons, or more specifically, speaking to raids requires quite a good internet connection as you carry anywhere from 4-8 players on your back. It's often hard to find raids to join that do not require you to be well-equipped, well-backed by your internet and beginner friendly for those unfamiliar with the way they work. Additionally, Nexon does not seem to have stable enough servers for large party raids requiring 16-24 people, which can halt a player's progression completely. Rather than being stable, the player-to-server ratio is very ill-managed.

Now I could go into the many other and much smaller issues that Vindictus has, such as the abismal drop rate for rare items, which is comparable to squeezing a diamond from a squirrel's behind, the stat fluxuation between armor and weapons from one level to the next, the chance meter for enhancements which fails about 70% of the time, the lack of character updates and gender locking, or even the fact that Nexon tries to make up for these issues by running events which can leave the user with a lot of useless and unsellable items to take up precious inventory space, but I think I've said enough.

All of these problems, which are serious drawbacks for players who really want to enjoy the game, can be put aside to a certain degree and the game, especially when played with a good team, can be distracting and immersive in the level of fun it creates. That being said, these problems together whether they're big or small seem to be the result of a mis-managed product that eventually becomes more of an expensive toy that repeatedly breaks and requires money to fix, than a free-to-play immersive fantasy game for people to enjoy together.

reviewText:
After 1246 hours and maxing 2 characters (mostly because I'm too lazy to max other characters, the second one took about 3 weeks to max), I feel I can write an appropriate review for this game.
It's great if you don't mind having to work for what you want. Be it grinding for pieces to make higher level weapons or armor. Joining a guild with people that you like is a big bonus as they can both help you improve and become great friends.
This game is best starting with a few people, you can easily do it alone, but obviously it's more fun with a group, as most things are.
The biggest complaint I've read in reviews is it being pay to win, but considering the most anyone pays for is underwear (best they give you really ugly long johns to start with) and other cosmetics, it's not really a big factor. You can be just as successful in the game playing during events, and grinding for what you need.
It's really a shame that the community is continuing to shrink, it really is a great game, especially for free. I have both an east and west coast character, the west seeming more of a stable economy, but the east seems more favoriable to newer players from what I've viewed.

reviewText: I didn't pay a single cent for this game, so I cannot complain too much. Maybe that's because I haven't reached a point yet where it's nearly impossible to do good without buying items, like most Free to Play (Pay to Win) games are. For now I am going to say no
recommended:
mainly because I am willing to see if it will get better the more I play, but not expecting too much.

As stated many times by other users, the gameplay can be boring and repetitive. I do get slight enjoyment out of slashing enemies, and some of the bosses are moderately fun, but overall the levels, A.I., story, and the world in general seem mediocre. I found myself clicking through most of what the characters were saying, and constantly wishing there was more to do (exploration, for one).

This is one of those games that is often painful to play for long periods of time, but also strangely (and uncomfortably) addictive.

reviewText:
PRO:
Great graphics
Fast-paced

CON:
Requires to spend real money to show more skin
Too many Chinese players using VPN
Shady people with picky requirements for raids
Constant server delays
Customer support doesn't exist (Unless you spend over $100)

Long review:
This game is Pay-to-Win (P2W), if you don't have enough attack or magic attack to filfull the requirement, you'll get kicked from the party, and the horrible peer-to-peer connection. The game is slowly dying, due to the people's desire for inner armors for female characters, Nexon wanting you to spend real money, power hungry people, and Nexon's horrible, horrible game server and customer service (Since when did they have customer service?), you'll get lagged every minute or so randomly.

Once you get yourself from level 1 to level 60 (Or 70), big boy raids are here. There are boats that wants party members to have the defense and/or attack required to get the raid go smooth as drinking an Iced Strawberry Brandy, but that's like last year or so, not sure how it is now. Not many people hosting raid boats now a days. Even when you do get in a raid boat, you just hope the host's connection is good or you'll be getting bad lag from the host itself, since it's Peer-to-Peer connections, not directly from the server. People can leave the party whenever if you're hosting if you have bad connections with them. You'll mostly be connected with people with three bars of connection (Most of the players are from China).

There is false advertisement when choosing a character to play as. Hot character showing lots of skins? Nope, you get a white overall instead of showing lots of skins. You'll be starting out with an inner armor that can only be changed by purchasing new hot inner armor with real money for $10 permanently, around half price for 30 days. Don't like the basic hair you can only choose when starting off? Better give them money to change it, around $8 for permanent or around half for 30 days. It's almost Freemium" tier.

Nexon wants you to spend NX for item shop badly. For say
date: you have a +5 equipment and want to go +6
recommended: but you fail regardless with the gamble of enhancing and goes back down by 1 level each. Got to +7? Want to +9? Hope you have enough material and money to afford the cost of the rank resets. The success rate for enhancement is extremely bad. There's a better solution to use protection rune to protect your equipment from losing it's enhancement. but for a cost of real money. And it's pricy for one protection rune

reviewText:
I played this way back when in 2011, and came back recently. I got back into the west coast server and was astounded on how much Vindictus decayed.

This game suffers from the WOW syndrome to an insane degree. The majority of the fanbase is very high level and you will rarely meet low level characters which leaves you with very little to work with.

You will have problems finding a party if you are a low level, and level 20 is considered very low level.

You will have problems finding people to do the main-quest-madatory raid with if you are low level.

So the game refuses to work with you unless you're high level and the amount of grind makes it not worth it. After all, why should someone invest so much time to even get to work with others on a regular basis? To work this hard to get into a community that has no guarantee to be welcoming or even good.

The game itself is good but the community is so lopsided that newcomers might as well not bother.

reviewText: An excellent action online game. I wouldn't call it an RPG necessarily, but it could be. If you had a bad day at work and need to brutally mutilate some monsters, this game is for you. It utilizes the Source engine for some great body physics as you slash, smash, burn and freeze your enemies. 6 different customizable characters to choose from each with a different play style. (combat styles are limited to characters and thus gender locked). The major downfall about this game is that its a free MMO, and thus can be glitchy and is prone to problems. These are not the fault of Steam or the game itself but more to do with the server issues of Nexon, which I don't feel is a very good company.
