reviewText: An amazing MMORPG. Despite some minor flaws here and there, Vindictus is surely a solid hack and slash that people will definitely enjoy. Even if it might not have the appeal of other similar titles, this game does stand out on its own through the diversity and uniqueness, so I certainly recommend it to all people interested in a fun hack and slash experience.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Vindictus is a hack n' slash MMO that was one of the first to effectively implement attack/dodge/block mechanics that you would see in any typical fighter such as Devil May Cry. Meaning that if an enemy is hit it's because the player is in range to land a blow properly...and if the player dodges or blocks then they avoided an attack by moving out of the way etc; no accuracy or avoid stats are present meaning that combat is inherently reliant on skill and learning attack patterns. A single player can solo the entirety of the game or hook up with some friends to ease the burden. I've played the game since beta and reached nearly maximum potential end-game with every character aside from Karok until I put it down some time after Regina was released NA. This review will be express my thoughts on the game in a Pros/Cons format.

Pros

+F2P - The game is free although it expresses a pay-for-convenience model with an in-game store. Everything in the game can be achieved for free assuming you are willing to be patient and wait/participate in events. Everything else in the store aside from pets are pretty much gambling and not worth the money...unless you're feeling lucky.

+Dress-up - If character customization and outfit creation is your thing, there's plenty of it in Vindictus. I suggest only spending money on cosmetics to customize your character level 70+ if you are buckling down for the long haul. My reasoning for this is that equipment that can be easily achieved with a little grinding for level 70 or higher gives huge power spikes and looks drastically different from sub 70 gear; it may not look very good with some cosmetic items that seemed to match lower level equipment.

+Diverse Cast - Rather than choosing a class Vindictus offers several preset characters that may be customized quite in-depth and have their own way of approaching fights as they level up and obtain skills to meet new challenges.

+Mission System - Queuing up for a mission consists of going to a Mission Board" with a list of sub-areas containing currently hosted quests for an area by other players. Selecting a quest (or hosting one) will transport the player to a lobby of sorts where they may wait for others to join
date: or choose to embark alone if you have no friends.\n\n+Combat - Fighting style depends on which character is chosen
recommended: however there are constants throughout all of them. Left-click launches "light" attacks which can combo into various "smash" attacks via right-clicking to end your light attack combo strings. Additionally
hoursPlayed: players will have a skillbar which will fill with a unique moveset to your chosen character as you level up. In optimal conditions combat is extremely fun and laggy fast-paced
voteText:
the best I've experienced in any MMO.

+Transformation - Level 40+ players gain access to a sub-quest line that will enable you to Bankai transform. You will have the choice between becoming a Dark Knight or a Paladin. Even though they offer different stats the forms are ultimately cosmetic end-game. The stats transformation offer are miniscule in comparison to the power given by gear so feel free to choose your side. May the Force be with you.

+Boss Fights - The main attraction of Vindictus. Over the top superbosses that are a blast to clash against. I have never played an MMO that has boss fights more fun than Vindictus.

Cons

-Leveling - To be frank it can put anyone to sleep
helpfulPercent: especially after having experienced it on multiple characters already. The entire appeal of Vindictus is the end-game bosses and the entire "constant" playerbase is at end-game. Meaning if you don't have a battle buddy you'll likely be running most of these boring grindfest missions alone.\n\n-Dull Story - The story lacks any real appeal. It's cheesy
votesHelpful: predictable
votesTotal:
and full of walking cliches.

-Market Board - The market is always suffering from price gouging. Players should stay away from buying items and strictly sell until you can deduce what items are worth.

-Drop Rates - Materials to create end-game gear has disgustingly low chance to drop. So much so that I've seen players run a boss for months every single day and not get what they need.

-Weapon/Armor Enhance System - Taking a weapon or armor piece to the forge allows the player to exchange gold and materials to enhance it. This will increase its power and eventually speed drastically (or defense in armors case). Enhancement is represented on a piece of gear with a +1-15 tacked on as a prefix. The higher gear enhances
votesFunny: the more likely it can fail. Failure can result in gear resetting to +0 or even destroying it. Destruction of a piece of gear can be reversed one time with the exchange of AP (ability points) accrued through missions
commentsCount:
but after that it'll be gone forever. The odds of achieving a high enhancement is stacked against the player heavily as a blatant cash grab via protection runes.

-Weapon/Armor Enchant System - The second layer of gear gambling to the Dark Souls difficulty equipment modification system is Enchanting. As you play the game you may stumble across enchantment scrolls. Scrolls are rated in a rank system of F-A to R9-R7. Failure of F-A scrolls will result in gear max durability loss. Failure of R9 or higher will likely cause item destruction unless you're willing to shell out money for runes to protect your gear on the chance of failure.

**Note** Enhancement/Enchant runes are given out during certain events for free if players are willing to wait for them
column16: just like every other cash shop item. However these runes do not modify the abysmal chance of success.\n\n-No Dedicated Servers - Aside from four gimmicky raids
column17: all missions are run off a peer player hosting the run. If the host has poor connection
column18: everyone lags. If the host has a lag spike so does everyone else. If the host disconnects the entire runs progress is lost and any consumables used are wasted. All boss drop rewards are passed out about 30 seconds after the boss dies
column19:
if you disconnect during this period you will recieve nothing. For a wealthy company like Nexon there is no reason for the game to not have dedicated servers other than being cheap.

-Poor Servers/Botters - The game itself has poor server performance at times of high traffic. Additionally because of botters (people running automated programs that play the game for them) the lag is much more intense and the market is flooded at random times. Ironically this lag goes away temporarily when these situations drive real players away from the game.

-Bugs - If you decide to get involved with Vindictus these are your new best friend. Almost every patch introduced breaks something else for an extended period of time. Random maintenance is a frequent occurance and they don't even resolve the problems half the time. At one point there was a bug that caused the game to crash when you opened your mailbox and put your mouse over an item. This was not fixed for nearly a year.

-Lack of Content - This may not be evident to a new player. However
column20: once you reach end-game this will make you question why you ever started playing at all. Nexon KR (Korea) is in charge of the games content creation. Meaning anything they get
column21: we will get patched into our game anywhere from three months to a year or more afterwards (if at all). If you're a steady player of the game then for those three months or more you'll be running the same end-game bosses over and over till you're bored to death of the boss fights that are supposed to be fun.\n\nTl;DR: After playing the game for so long I really wanted to make a positive review. However I couldn't do so in good conscience after thinking it all over. Good concept torn apart by Nexon's haphazard care/greed. Don't waste your time."

reviewText:
If I remember correctly, this game is the reason I downloaded steam, and sure enough it was worth it, for a while. My play time may be deceiving, because the majority of it came shortly after I downloaded Vindictus.

First off, the characters are all unique both in appearance and feeling, as well as gameplay. Great. The gameplay itself is much more satisfying than any other MMORPG I've ever played. The way you position your character, the multitude of different combos you utilize by threading both attacks and spells together literally blew my my mind with every drop of gnoll blood I splatted upon the cold, cursed ground.

I love the combat mechanics in this game, and I always will-

But the story is simply lackluster. It's hard to explain, because the story is there and there's really nothing wrong with it, but its execution is just bad. I'm not sure if there is a single character model for any of the NPCs in the game. The fact that you never see commander so-and-so fight ANYONE, or general whats-her-face kill ANYBODY, or any of these supporting characters DO ANYTHING, it makes you feel alone, and that makes for a very weak story.

The story also suffers from sheer repetition in each level. Go through these ruins, kill these dogs, repeat. Same ruins, same dogs, repeat. OH WAIT A BO- aaaaaand it's just a big dog with a similar attack pattern abusable by anyone with half a brain.
Okay new area. Icy tunnels. Goblins. Bigger goblin. Repeat. Tunnels. Goblins. Bigger Goblin. Repeat.

Mind-numbing.

I like this game, I really do, and I would recommend it to anyone, especially because it's free.
But in summary this game is a testament as to why you cant make a game great with gameplay alone.

reviewText: Not going to lie. This game looked promising at first. The prologue was great and the combat system was also pretty good. However, everything changes as soon as you finish the prologue. The UI becomes extremely cluttered with ridiculous things like facebook like buttons and other useless things. Not only that but after the prologue the game becomes extremely laggy. Also the mouse cursor is off when trying to click on buttons in any menu. You have to click below the button for it to register the click. I would not recommend playing this game unless you don't care about those things. I'm sure if I had played the game for longer then I may have looked past all of those things eventually, but I didn't want to put in the effort nor time.\n\nOverall rating: 5/10

reviewText:
Vindictus a game I've played in the past and continue to return in hopes of its improvement, only to be upset time and time again.

The game has great potential, but appears to be lacking in many aspects that make it a game I would recommend. My highest characters are nearing their 50s, and I've gotten that far with 3 different characters. This is entirely based off of my experience and the experience of others I have played with. I have participated in some endgame content such as dragon raids, which I found to be fun even though I died a lot, but I will not be covering that in this review.

Combat

++ Physics
++ Classic Hack and Slash
+ Greater" Raids offer unique gameplay not seen as much in the Story

+- Fun w/ killing your friends via the environment
+- Spear Throw friend/foe (does no damage to friend)
+- Fluid and seamless depending on your specs
recommended:
settings

- "Greater" Raids require 16 players to start
- Repetitive use of Skills
- Becomes more repetitive the higher your level

Gameplay

++ Limitless amount of AP (skill points) to spec every skill
+ Gold is an easily obtainable resource
+ Quests sometimes chain through completion (Doing one dungeon sometimes completes two quests)

- Storage is Limited unless you pay and a lot of resources are necessary for quests/crafting
- Linear Environment/Dungeons
- Linear Quest Line
- Linear Way to Kill Bosses - 1 Strategy is usually the most effective and used above all other strategies
- Bosses an enemies do not vary much every 10 levels
- Repeating the same dungeon more than twice - becomes more repetitve at higher levels
- As you level drop rates on items for quests become lower
- Upgrading is high risk or extremely expensive (RNG)

UI

+ Titles

- Cannot View channel location of friends via friend list
- Cannot View location of friends on the minimap
- Cannot Search for Unadded Friends in Friend Menu
- Emotes are hidden need to be googled
- Marketplace/Guild Search appear to be quite slow and may be using Internet Explorer
- Inactive Guilds die
hoursPlayed:
leadership is not transferred

Cash Shop

+ Some of the greatest quality and entertaining costumes and goodies excessible in the RPG world

+- Nexon makes money primarily from costumes and so it appears to have become the focus of the game
+- Almost every second patch has a new costume
+- Wealth of a player shines
voteText:
people will take their time to oggle you

- Players more interested in costumes than the actual gameplay
- Overpriced AND Restricted relative to other RPGs (common in many Nexon games)
- A bum is still a bum if they enter this game
helpfulPercent:
the costumes and cash shop content are promoted so much that many active players end up buying it and new players or those that cannot afford it feel pressured or distaste.

Other

+ Controls are fair
votesHelpful:
supporting 3 modes

+- You use the same armor/weapon for most of the game

- Bugs take years to fix
- Sound quality is average
- Music is repetitive
- Monster cries
votesTotal:
screams repetitive

Last thoughts:

This is a game you want to play with friends
votesFunny: preferrably join a guild or create one for the exp boost when you party together. This game a lot of perks to group play
commentsCount: but is not as rewarding to solo players."

reviewText:
This has to be in one of my most favorite MMOs of all time, ive played Vindictus a lot more off-steam than on steam and what i can say is that one of it's greatest strengths is it actually improves a lot and often through updates and patches even so many years after release. To be honest, i was very disapointed in vindictus when it first launched, and about just as disapointed a year later, but when i did come back to it this summer, i felt like everything i've ever wanted in an MMO was now a part of this game.

Pros:
-Amazing Combat System , arguibly the best feature of the game.
-Decent customization system for character and gear.
-Lots of fun characters(classes) , most with 2 weapons (completely different playstyles usually).
-The more you learn and the further you get, it will only intrigue you more rather than bore you like most MMOs.
-Good Trademarket/auction house
-Good events, rewards, freebies, etc.
-Most stuff you pay for is either small boosts to exp and drop rates or just cosmetics. (unless you count the temporary mid lvl (50-60) you can buy , which you can also get from redeployment packages for free.
-Absolutely BEAUTIFUL visuals, graphics, animations, characters, mobs, etc.
-Lots of rich characters and stories and information to be learnt if interested (more of a con for me).

Cons:
-Lots and i mean LOTS of some what annoying text/chat bubbles from characters.
-to level up quests are practically neccesary (that includes a lot of side quests)
-The most Frowned upon part (that i havnt personally had much of an issue with) is that dungeons and instances are peer to peer connection.
-Price difference of good mid-high level equips to great mid-high level equips to end-game equips is quite noticeable.
-Requires some what of an actual graphic card and processor (not saying high end or even mid-tier, but you cant expect to play on an intel hd graphics or a very outdated low-end graphic card and get good frames).
-underwear/underarmor sticks out of some armors and the defaults are plain white tights that can only be replaced by other under garments for real money (per character).


Overall: this game might have been less fun in comparison to similar games like dragon nest, c9, diablo, etc in its earlier days, but now it outclasses them in certain different ways. i simply hope they make end game gear more approachable, let more ppl from more regions play the game, and with an actual server sided hosting system. but some of these things might just be too much to ask for. Well at least untill black desert comes out (if it's as good as the hype) this will be my goto and favorite MMO.

reviewText:
Vindictus asks; What are you willing to put up with to play a game totally unlike any other MMO out there?

The gameplay is fast, fun, and has that perfect 'easy to learn, hard to master' feel to it. Grouping up with other people to take down a behemoth of a boss is one of those can't miss moments.

With that said, the other aspects of the game are pretty terrible. Lag is ever present, even on high end PCs. DC's are (at least for me) near constant. Nexon's support is mediocre at the best of times. A lot of late game content is locked behind item mall purchases. This list could go on for much longer but I'll stop it now.

I played Vindictus years ago and enjoyed the hell out of it. Dropped due to above reasons and came back to see if at least the preformance bugs were handled only to be disappointed.

It is free to download though so give it a shot, see if it works, and enjoy what you can out of it.

reviewText:
I want to recommend this game, I really do. I didnt get very far though, only to level 20 or so. The last time I played it was around a year ago, too.

The main part of the game is the hack-and-slash segments with a little bit of exploring thrown in, but the fighting gets very repetitive. The stages are just recycled. They were too lazy to even change the layout most of the times. All they did was put the enemies in new spots. Leveling was very grindy. When you found a weapon better than the one you were using at the moment, you were lucky. I kept a lvl 8 or 10 weapon until I stopped playing. The fastest way to get better gear was to use the market.

And now the part that turned me off the most;  account pin code. When you first started the game, you were prompted to make a pin code, so as to not have someone log into your account and delete all of your characters and stuff. The thing is though, you forget that code, forget your chances of ever playing on those characters again. I didnt bother to contact support though, seeing as how that I didnt really have a desire to play the game again.

Overall, the game is good. It is just the company that ruined it. It had a very good design and a very poor execution. Like I mentioned at the top, I didnt get very far. I just couldnt push myself to grind through the repetitive levels over and over and over just to find something that had +5 damage over my current weapon.

reviewText:
Vindictus has been dead for quite some time now, the cash shop is atrocious, typical nexon events include 1% chances in gacha of getting a rare item and rewarded for afking events. There is zero customer support what so ever, the servers are very unstable and always have been.

Dont get me wrong, the gameplay itself is fantastic and one of a kind but everything else has completely ruined the experience for me. Gold farming bots have been taking over vindictus since the release date and has destroyed the economy of most items making it so players just spend their own money to get top tier items without actually putting in the grind to earn it themselves.

End game content is alright, your forced to buy enchant runes that fail/blow up at a 40% chance on top tier scrolls, dungeons hardly exist anymore and if you find one they are most likely with an attack requirement(19k-21k atk) which some new players who haven't spent any real money most likely will not be able to join.

reviewText:
A great game made by the worst MMO company in the History of online gaming called Nexon whom I will refer to as Shixon in this review.   Save yourself the trouble, and do not play this game it's a waste of time and money.

Problems

*#1.   If the vast skies were scrolls and the endless oceans were ink, I could not write enough bad things about any Shixon run game, this game is no exception.

*#2Servers are absolutely horrible.   You wll get disconnected, you will lag, you will not be able to play the game properly no matter what server you are on.   The community has complained to Shixon about this, but it seems like they are unwilling to upgrade their 56k dialup internet connection.

*#3Bots.   As with any Shixon made game, bots are a problem.   Not only do the millions of them that ruin this game cause severe server lag, but they also destroy the economy and other areas of the games completely.   Right when you first start playing the game on Channel 1, you'll be greated by Bots standing right in the middle of town trying to steal your credit card information by selling gold for cash.   Shixon has been unable to catch these bots even though they stand right in the middle of town yelling to everyone.   DO you think it's safe to give your credit card information to hackers?    Shixons lack of action against these bots shows that Vindictus is also a risk to your financial information and identity.   You might spend $100 on your credit card on premium items only to have some hacker spend $10,000 on your credit card for a vacation to another country.

*#4Shixon.   This argueably should always be the first problem anyone mentions when reviewing a game made by this company.   This is the worst online gaming MMO company that has ever been formed.

*#5Poorly thought out events, drunk moderaters is the only explanation.    Imagine that you played the game for a year or so, we all know how these MMO's work.   You play the game and work hard to get your high level gear which can take MONTHS on this game.   The day you get your high level gear you realize that Shixon has decided to run an event which practicly gives new players the same gear you have, and for free.   What do you get for being a  level 85 player who contributed to the game since the start?   20 healing potions.   Yes this really did just happen.   Typical Shixon.

*#6Unoptimized engine.   You can have a 5 GHZ (Turbo) 8 Core liquid cooled AMD 9590/Nvidia 660TI/OC and the game will still find random ways to stutter despite the fact that I can play newer games like Wolfenstein the New order on max everything at 1080P without a stutter or hitch.   This is due to a poorly optimized engine that does not use multiple cores what so ever at any point in time during playing.   Intel Cpus are better for this game due to the pathetic level of coding since Intel Cpu's are usually rated better on single threaded applications.


The Good.

This can be summed up in one paragraph, at the core this is a great action hack n slash game.   You'll play this game and say wow this is really great, this guy reviewing it must be crazy.    Then you'll keep playing the game and realize everything I said was true a month down the road and you'll instantly wish you had the last month of your life back.

Save yourself the trouble my friends, friends don't let friends play Vindictus.

reviewText:
Here's some things you should know about this game;
Levelling isn't easy unless you have quests to turn in, but the quests are sometimes very long and tedious. Sometimes it takes hours to even go up one level.
This game is near impossible to play alone, so if you planned on doing so don't even bother. Many of the battles are tough and will require more than one person, or countless hours of levelling yourself up to do them alone.
Aquiring armour and weapons at higher levels over 60 isn't easy or cheap. You pretty much have to make them yourself and it takes a lot of work and I mean A LOT of work or lots gold to buy the pieces.
The game gets very repetative. Collect blah blah from battle blah blah. Now go back into the same battle 2 more times and collect new items.
Game not recommended past the first 30 levels. :l

reviewText:
Real-time action combat. Actually real-time. If you don't lag (it is much better nowadays).  Joined in 2009, seen the game improve tremendously, and I still play to this day.

Back then, there was not that many instances to run through, so the game would become somewhat quickly repetitive. However, there are now more than 15 episodes that each contain a specific set of instance(s), boss(es) and raid boss(es). Oh, and weapons and armor sets.

It is at least worth trying out, especially if you like action RPGs like games from the Souls series (or Bloodborne). But it's free to play.

Real. Time. (I put emphazis on this, as many MMOs claim to be real-time, but they are not)

reviewText:
Here's some things you should know about this game;
Levelling isn't easy unless you have quests to turn in, but the quests are sometimes very long and tedious. Sometimes it takes hours to even go up one level.
This game is near impossible to play alone, so if you planned on doing so don't even bother. Many of the battles are tough and will require more than one person, or countless hours of levelling yourself up to do them alone.
Aquiring armour and weapons at higher levels over 60 isn't easy or cheap. You pretty much have to make them yourself and it takes a lot of work and I mean A LOT of work or lots gold to buy the pieces.
The game gets very repetative. Collect blah blah from battle blah blah. Now go back into the same battle 2 more times and collect new items.
Game not recommended past the first 30 levels. :l

reviewText:
Even with the update to make leveling easier on this game, farming is still a necesity to get anywhere without you shelling out some money (and the farming is painful in this game due to low drop rates). The characters also have enough diversity to suit most people's playstyle; a lot of the weapons unique and not-so-generic. The story isn't exactly engaging but it's adequate (I myself read the dialogue and see some humor sprinkled here and there).

The main reason why I still continue to play this game is because the combat is so fun!

Despite its shortcomings with a heavily chance-based enchanting/enhancing system and repetitive farming, I still recommend this game because the gameplay is enjoyable, fast-paced, and intense. That's what makes Vindictus different from other MMORPGs at the moment.

Side note, however: Lag seems to be a pretty large con" in this game. It relies on P2P (peer-to-peer) hosting for running dungeons
date:
which is the only method of completing battles in this game (another "con"). There is also some server instability during large events.

---EDIT DEC 2015---

I have officially ceased playing this game because I have a backlog to clear

reviewText:
I only merged my Nexon account with Steam so I can use my Steam Wallet, so this isn't some prematurely written review. I have a reasonable amount of experience with the game (4 characters over 75 and many above 50).

With that being said I'll start with the pros, or what made it attractive FOR ME.
The combat is simply amazing. It's fast paced yet fluid and responsive, versitile yet easy to learn. The reason why I stuck with the game for so long was because I wanted to try out every character's skills (with my favorite being Lann). You will rarely find a game with combat as action packed as Vindictus.

Although it is instance based, Vindictus does a good job of making sure that the environment does not get too bland. Doungeons are has enough differences that you will never feel like you're just doing the same level again (with very little exceptions). This is achieved with difference in themes, maps (of course), traps (and not too many of them), and interactive elements.

Now, the factors that made me quit.

The story. It's pretty engaging and interesting... if it's your first time playing it. It follows the genderless and universal hero formula as all other one-path MMORPG storyline. No (interesting) sidequests to explorer, no extra content. The whole game is just sending you from place to place and instance to instance.

The fact that you can buy almost everything with NX. If you've played old school Maplestory, you'd know about Nexon's mistake (or not since they probably milked those whales dry). In Vindictus, Nexon applies the same principle. You can buy almost anything in the game as long as you have the NX. From potions and revives to skill points and endgame gear. Yes, it is a skill based game, but think about it... being able to heal to full hp almost instantly, reviving without penalty, and all the damage boost. When I bought my first skill capsule (skill points), I thought to myself... wow all those hours wasted grinding dailys was kind of pointless." I immediately lost a bit of passion for this game.

Overally
recommended: it's worth the first playthrough. It's something to pick up during your one week break and then let go as soon as something better comes up.\n\n"

reviewText:
All I can say is the combat system can be fun and the story is alright. But that's about it.

The game is plagued by gold sellers which has in turn caused an incredibly inflated economy on trade materials revolving around the crafting/enhance system. When you can buy 100million gold for $13 and then buy all the trade materials off the market place...yeah...I've already earned close to 1million gold by just selling trade materials and haven't even reached level 15. Some trade goods go for about 100,000g each, while some weapons and gear sell for about 1,000g.

On top of that, this game runs like trash. It's an unopimitized heap of trash. HUGE framerate spikes. Stuttering from anywhere about 10fps to 40fps in an area as you simply stand there...makes no sense and is incredibly frustrating.

On top of it all, the dungeons and enemies can become incredibly bland and boring as there is very little to zero variety. In the end, the combat system is the only thing it has going for it.

reviewText:
First, I played several hours prior to the arrival of this game on steam.

It is a good and enjoyable game without a doubt. The gameplay is nice, the progression too, graphics are nice and all. So, why no reccommend it? Easy to say. Nexon have little to none support. you spend money in the game, you might or might not get what comes with it, what you will surely get is no answer from their part.

Good features
- Great gameplay, varies depending on the character and weapon type.
- Graphics are nice.
- Music isn't bad, not great but it's enjoyable.
- Story is brought in a more Japanesse way, which isn't bad, but don't expect big cinematics as the story is more textual.

Bad features
- Customer support is a myth (I heard that a few people could get an answer from their part, but I never got any)
- Real money spent in the game might end up split into two different pool of currency making you unable to buy the stuff you put money in for. (That is if you get some in-game currency for that hardly gained real money)
- Servers are often buggy and/or down
- There is a lot of connection issue known with this game.
- Hacking is a common ground around Nexon account (or so it seems, I actually got my main character's gear stolen, but I used a not-too-secure password, otherwise this point is more about what I've read on the community forums of Nexon at the time I tried to get my money back for a purchase that they did not give what was paid for).

Verdict : It is a game to try, but never to invest real money in.

reviewText:
This game makes me want to rip the skin off my face and eat it.... Pretty sure that would be more fun and better use of my time than it is.

Now that we've got that out of the way.....

I played this game a lot before it was on steam, I had no money at the time and a friend that loved it to death.
He got me playing it to pass the time, as I had nothing better to do and and my aforementioned activity had not yet occurred to me, I went for it.

At first glance the game seems alright, a nice cast of characters, a mediocre customization menu, the game doesn't look too shabby graphically, and it was free.

Then I started walking.... The animation was smooth, so smooth in fact that I seemed to be sliding my feet along the ground, only moving about half as fast as my animation suggested I should be.. So I turned and ran to the left and I glided along in a way that could almost be compared to a cat trying to gain traction on a recently waxed floor, I mean I did turn, just not in the way one might expect a human to move across dirt and grass.

I got to a combat section and because thought to myself This is where the game will redeem itself!!" but I was Let down by this as well! It's by no means awful
date: but in my eyes it was typical
recommended: it didn't do anything I hadn't seen before and the execution of the system didn't wow me either
hoursPlayed: It lacked polish.\n\nThat's when things started getting weird
voteText: suddenly I noticed that my character's physics would randomly spaz out while I was standing still
helpfulPercent:
parts of her armor and/or body would jolt around like a kid who's had too much sugar. And I would randomly become stuck at odd angles against terrain during combat

Lets move on from all of that though.

I feel like I should mention a few more things that struck me as odd...
There are more loading screens in this game than you can shake a stick at. You wanna go to the docks where you access the missions? Loading screen! You wanna start a mission? Loading screen
votesHelpful: which then leaves you on a tiny dock with a boat on it. You wanna start the mission for real this time? Loading screen!!!!! Just when you think that's all of 'em done
votesTotal: you kill a few baddies and walk a little ways... LOADING SCREEN!!!! I think you get the picture...\nThe camera controls are shockingly sluggish for an ARPG.\nThey call it an MMO
votesFunny:
it's not an MMO it's a Co-Op multiplayer ARPG with a giant chat room where you can find up to 4 players to run missions with you.
You need to use real money for most of the cool looking stuff.

TLDR: The game claims to be things it isn't. It's not an awful game it's just a huge let down.
If you like the concept of this game play Warframe

reviewText:
Been playing this game on and off for 3 years now. Here is what i have to say:

Game itself is fantastic and actually fairly challenging to master. Many people have mentioned the sharp learning curve in raids, and I won't deny it does take effort, time and practice to get used to each boss, but in my honest opinion that's what makes this game unique and awesome. It is not a simple brainless point and click adventure like most other MMOs out there but actually takes quite a bit of skills to play well. You actually feel good after beating something. This is one of those games that defense is not that important once you can master it.

In a nutshell, raids/raid bosses are where this game is mostly at. You do raids, gather seal of braveries and craft lv70 gears which would allow you to join those silly attack boats in Season 2. Acquiring 12 seals a day is perhaps the most efficient way to get gears up to speed, so you can have enough stats to do kraken and lakoria for their drops. You can choose to farm, but that is imho very time consuming and not worth the return you'd get. Instead, play 1-2 hours a day with a guild, run the raids of your choices + lakoria and kraken (mandatory, they are easy raids with valuable drops) and grab all the seals on all the characters you can.


Since I mentioned characters, let's just say some characters are more powerful than the others. Certain character in this game has been pretty bad since 2011 and is still pretty bad lel. (aka that male character everyone thought was so cool holding 2 swords and looked like he would decimate everythng in this game but turned out he was the one who always got decimated for making 1 mistake huehuehue), and certain characters are a lot harder to gear up to the attack boat requirements.

What I recommend is to roll one of these characters as your first character for now (in order of most recommended to least: hurk/arisha - kai - vella - lynn - Karok/evie/Fiona) and wait for the dual-sword character buff coming (test server in KR for now). The ones I listed are pretty fun as they are actually, and should keep you busy for a long time.


So, to fully enjoy this game, I recommend:

1). Spending enough to make a good weapon that can bring you up to 15-16k attack. How good the weapon has to be is up to you. I'd say to do end game lv80 dungeons, a +10 lv70 nighthawk is perhaps the best option for most people before they get hold of a lv80 weapon. They are good cheap weapons and very easy to make. Doing this is to join all these stupid S2 attack requirement boats.

2). Have a decent computer to be able to run this game at 60fps in DX8. Otherwise you will not get the most out of it. Hardware from 2011/2012 is more than capable of this. Recommend an intel processor because this game hates AMD processor.

OPTIONAL: if you choose to host 8-man dungeon, make sure your internet is at least 2mbps upload, in addition to meeting the 2012 pc requirement.

3). Overlook the bad things Nexon does, and take full advantage of good things they do.

What I mean by this is that we all know how Nexon works as a company if you have played any of their games, and you can QQ as loud as you can, but every now and then they do some events and all that which are actually good for the players, and you don't wanna miss those just because how much personal grudge you hold against them. Things like giveaway, events etc. are for us, and we need to get all of them.

Meanwhile get on forum and QQ/vent all you want when something goes wrong, because some of these issues have been there for YEARS and still not completely fixed. Cough cough server hamsters etc.

4). Avoid rolling a dual sword character as your first character for the reason I have described above.

5). Avoid too much farming for reason I described above.

6). Focus on the gameplay and raid boss fights. Treat it as an action game and work on how you can improve and do better.

reviewText:
Until I played this game I gave very little consideration to Free to Play MMOs. Normally they are so pay to win it hurts. However Vindictus has turned out to be one of my all time favorite games I think I have ever played. It has definately come a long ways since I started playing it.

The graphics are nice considering this game only runs on DX9. If you enjoy a more linear game progression then this would would be great for you. The dev team still add new content every few months and there is always community events, especially during holidays.

This is a very solid game and is definately worth at least checking out.

reviewText:
*sighs*
as of 6-17-2014 I can no longer recoemend Vindictus.

Nexon's greed and Devcats incompentence is slowly but steadly driving the game into the dirt.

Firstly, there is the removeal of the jumping mechanic. Granted it was poorly implemented to begin with, but instead of opting to fix it, the instead removed it, and sunsquently reworked all of seaon 2, map lay out and enemys, to compenstate for the player no longer being able to jump.

Secondly, they actually removed the option to run season 2 from levels 8-49. Because high level players where farming them for Seals (needed to buy high end mats) and AP (needed to rank up skills, some of which need 2 or 3k per rank and you at best, getting 250) so again, instead of fixing the issue, they just removed a chunk of the game.

Then there what Nexon it self is doing, since Devcat isn't the only one ruining this thing.

The cash shop is starting to lean toward a 'pay2win' model, granted, it's still a LONG way from that, but it's starting down that road, from the overpriced pets who grant extra, and rather potentant effects like buffs or mining ore for you, to the laughably over priced Enchantment, and Enhancement Runes that are pretty much required to be usefull in the 70-80 tier content,

The 'events' are pretty much ONLY for lining Nexon pockets with money, with what ever free items being little more then the cheapest items in the cash shop, while what ever good items that are attatched are only attainable vai 'random item' boxes you buy from the cash shop, with a rather horrible chance of actually getting the event item, as you'd probably expect.

Speaking of the RNG, It's horrible here. Drop rates have always been bad in this game, but pretty much any equipment worth using level 60 and up requires AT LEAST one ultra rare mateiral drop, per piece, and I don't mean 'I've been farming for a week and finally got one' rare, I mean 'this raid has been out for a year, I've been running it daily, still haven't gotten the drop I need' rare. Sadly, I'm not exagerating ether.

The RNG ties into the final issue I want to mention. the price of things. The amount of gold you need to cercumvent the drop rates is prohibitive to every one who isn't willing to risk getting ripped off to buy gold. the Seal Shop, which sells the ultra rare mateirs you need, is suppossed to combat the drop rate issue, but it really just added to the grind problem, with some taking anywhere from 5 days, to more then a month of JUST Seal farming to get. (12 seals per day, 1 seal per raid run, 1 victory per raid a day)

The actual gameplay it self is still fun, but Nexon effectively destoryed what ever potental it had utterly through greed and imcompatence. The game is dieing, and at this point, I say let it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I've been playing it since the open beta 2 years ago

Vindictus is an action based MMO the centers on instances, and TRUE SKILL when fighting bosses. to win you need to learn a bosses tells and openings, you gear, even maxed out, only makes up about 10%, at best, of your odds of winning, the rest is on you, the player.

armor and weapons must be made by gathering matierals from bosses anf raid bosses, with the only short cut being the auction house, and even then all gear has a level and skill requirement, even the stuff in the cash shops weapon/armor packs, which are filled with imporved gear, you can make on your own with out spending a dime.

the cash shop it self is mostly about convienace, potions, graces and invintory space will likely be the bulk of your purchices, along with some avatar items to make you character look better.

all in all, it is a good game that deserves more attention then its gotten, and despite what Tera says, Vindictus IS the first true action MMO

reviewText:
I really and truly want to give this game a positive review, but I simply cannot bring myself to.

To start, Vindictus is an MMORPG and Hack n' Slash game that really misses the MMO portion of its genre. It has features of one, like a global marketplace and raids and the sort, but it stops there. There are only two cities in the entire game and a field that seperates them with little activity in either one. Aside from queing for battles, there isn't much to do in the locations, there's crafting and quest givers that can provide some interesting dialouge, but it stops there. Honestly, this isn't too much of a problem compared to the more pressing problems I have with the game.

Gameplay is very solid, however, the skill tree for each of the playable characters is very diverese as each character is allowed to use two different weapons in their class; such as a mage who can choose to use a scythe or a staff or a tank that can use either a pillar or cestus as a weapon. Each provide their own strengths and weaknesses in their own regard and I found it enjoyable learning the combos and intricacies of each weapon and skill.

Unfortunately, the pros for the game stop at the gameplay. The largest problem I have with the game is the developer; for those that don't know, Nexon is a very greedy company. The in-game store offers a range of items that either change the cosmetic appearance or provide a game breaking and pay-to-win experiance like buying items that buff your stats to paying to allow yourself to do more raids, it's downright criminal. The downfall of this also comes into the heafty price they ask for literally EVERYTHING. Just to change the hairstyle of your character (as you can only choose about 5 when you first start, then have to pay, seperately, for the additional 20 Nexon expects you to buy) runs you about $7. Want to change your clothes? $10. Want to be able to do more daily raids? $10.

Another serious problem with Nexon is their support for the game. While the branches of Nexon in various other areas of the world like in Europe or Asia recieve timely patches to the game that actually provide new content like new characters, new locations, new raids, etc. The Nexon supporting this version, Nexon NA, is the about the most incompetent company I have seen. Instead of working on updates that the community has been begging for, they keep making new events that act as little mini-games or side missions you can do that, SURPRISE, you have to pay real money in order to even finish, and sometimes even participate in.

Probably the largest problem I have with the game, despite how dreadful the company is, is the absoltuely absurd grind that you have to do at high levels. The main story lasts from levels 1-60, which is not that bad and you may end up being overleveled for some missions you must do, but after you finish the main story comes the real pain. From 60, the level cap is 80, and you can obtain the best weapons and armor in the game, but in order to do this requires you to not only grind many, many hours away hoping you get the materials required to make a weapon or piece of armor, but to withstand the god awful drop rate that about every item has. The drop table is about as bad as the enhancing and upgrading system in the game. To make matters worse, in order to even get the item you need, you have to grind raids. Remember what I said about how greedy Nexon was? Well you can only run the raids you need about 3 times or so a day, so if you really want those materials, you better pull out your wallet because grinding that raid is gonna cost you extra.

Honestly, I really want to recommend this game to everyone, but unless this game gets taken over by a more respectable and competent company, I simply can't.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Like many reviews have said, this game is hosted by Nexon and suffers greatly for it. The cash shop gives a certain advantage of time, where some players must grind and farm the same boss over and over day after day hoping to pick up the rare crafting item they need with a 10% drop rate, cash shop players can simply buy it on the spot. Power ups can be rarely obtained from special events, but the majority are from the cash shop, and they give such an advantage that a level 40 player with amazing gear could be owned with ease in pvp by a level 30. The progression system gets old as well, since the ENTIRE game is about killing stuff, expect to see the same enemies a level or two higher each time you do a quest, add in the occasional boss, until you reach the next area. Oh, and you can't get your hands on that ingredient you need to finally complete the armor you wanted? No problem my friend, just stop by the marketplace, after 2-3 minutes of waiting for the marketplace HOME page to load, you can now purchase your rediculously overpriced item which will drain you of that 10 hours money grind you did.

Finally, there are the raid battles, where the REAL fun in this game starts. At level 20 you can start your first raid battle, which is a bunch of people all fighting a GIANT monster, usually a dragon. Sounds like fun right? Wrong, the matchmaking system takes an hour to pair 10 people together, and you need 15 to start. The first thing you'll notice when you start is, 1) there are at least 3 players YOUR level with absolutely overpowered gear from the cash shop, 2) there will be people sitting in the back, often your healers, doing nothing but spamming the chat, 3) surprise surprise and happy birthday, you cannot deal substantial damage to the boss until you're at least 20 levels above it. no worries though, hit the boss once and stand back like the healers, you get the same reward as everyone else for just standing around with your thumb up your ♥♥♥. The worst part about raid battles though, is the daily restriction on how many times you can run them, at high levels this doesn't matter as much seeing as you have access to multiple raids (each one has it's own daily counter thank god), but again don't expect to do much to the boss at all unless you've reached a much higher level than it's requirements or paid $50 in the cash shop for end game gear.

My recommendation is to not play this game, I had fun for a while and you can too, but eventually you reach a point where you'd rather strip all your armor off, unequip your weapon and just yolo into a boss naked because, hey why not those cash shop players do and they never die right?

Oh, and you can't get your hands on that ingredient you need to finally complete the armor you wanted? No problem my friend, just stop by the marketplace, after 2-3 minutes of waiting for the marketplace HOME page to load, you can now purchase your rediculously overpriced item which will drain you of that 10 hours money grind you did.

Finally, there are the raid battles, where the REAL fun in this game starts. At level 20 you can start your first raid battle, which is a bunch of people all fighting a GIANT monster, usually a dragon. Sounds like fun right? Wrong, the matchmaking system takes an hour to pair 10 people together, and you need 15 to start. The first thing you'll notice when you start is, 1) there are at least 3 players YOUR level with absolutely overpowered gear from the cash shop, 2) there will be people sitting in the back, often your healers, doing nothing but spamming the chat, 3) surprise surprise and happy birthday, you cannot deal substantial damage to the boss until you're at least 20 levels above it. no worries though, hit the boss once and stand back like the healers, you get the same reward as everyone else for just standing around with your thumb up your ♥♥♥. The worst part about raid battles though, is the daily restriction on how many times you can run them, at high levels this doesn't matter as much seeing as you have access to multiple raids (each one has it's own daily counter thank god), but again don't expect to do much to the boss at all unless you've reached a much higher level than it's requirements or paid $50 in the cash shop for end game gear.

My recommendation is to not play this game, I had fun for a while and you can too, but eventually you reach a point where you'd rather strip all your armor off, unequip your weapon and just yolo into a boss naked because, hey why not those cash shop players do and they never die right?

reviewText:
It's technically an MMO, but it plays like a multiplayer action game.

This interesting hybrid of gameplay styles works wonderfully.

In addition, Vindictus is compatible with xbox 360 controllers, and works quite well with them during dungeons. You'll still want a keyboard and mouse handy for the town areas and for typing and UI selections though.

I find it difficult to enjoy most MMO titles, but this one really feels like you're playing an action title. The gameplay is fast paced and action oriented. Dungeons are initially doable solo, but eventually the difficulty ramps up too high for that.

Thankfully, joining random groups is simple and streamlined. Quest and mission objectives are usually very straightforward and areas are fairly linear for the most part, so teaming up and working together with other players is rarely a chore or hassle.

The story is a bit on the weak side, but the gameplay is the star of the show, and it shines brightly.

reviewText:
Ever wanted to be truly rewarded for your skill in a game? How about some action, RPG, and a whole lotta hack'n'slash? Vindictus is that game. Taking place thousands of years before the fantasy life MMORPG, Mabinogi, another Nexon title -- this game is definitely not about picking wool off a sheep or raising crops on a field. This is the most simple yet highly complex Action MMORPG out right now.

Many have tried to emulate this style of MMO but Vindictus had laid forth a tyrant of an action game. Running on Valve's Source engine, the detail level of this game is simply gorgeous, the physics are top-notch (hilarious rag doll physics included), and monster AI will prove to give you a run for your golds at higher difficulties.

Vindictus is mainly a dungeon crawling Action MMORPG with hub to dungeon travel via Story /Quest Boards and some stages may look repetitive and they are but as you keep playing, you'll find many other things to do.

Welcome to the Vindictus where skill matters..

reviewText:
Season 3 is out, and I'm assuming more people are flocking over to the game or returning.

The game is fun, combat is fast and clean. Plenty of characters to choose from, and the graphics are crisp and clean. I don't play on steam cause my account is on a different email so my hours aren't accurately represented. Early on it may seem like a fine game, and it really is. But level 60 and above is where the game forces you to grind for gear unless you want to pay some large sums of gold to buy it instead. Gear also needs to be enhanced, and that can be a real headache since items can be destroyed or reset unless you have a rune (which is usually bought with real money). It's a long and tiring grind unless you got some real good luck, so I suggest you play with friends, join a guild, or do something to keep you interested in the game because this grind is going to become a common part of the game when you reach the higher levels. In fact, I HIGHLY suggest you get yourself and your friends/buddies/whatever to play together, cause playing alone can get boring when you're grinding for hours.

Pros
- Great combat with intense and fast battles.
- The game looks real good, and the gear makes you look cool.
- Plenty of characters with their own kind of playstyles. Some have a 2nd weapon which also changes their fighting style.
- Lots of content, the game has been here for quite a while, and more is being added. (Season 3)
- Community is welcoming, guilds will usually be willing to tell you about the game and such.
- Plenty of character customization.
- The grind is worth it considering how badass you will look with all that glorious gear. So work hard! (Or not.)
- Did I forget to mention how cool you will look? (no really.)

Cons
- Atrocious drop rates on items you need for gear.
- Gearing up can be VERY gold/time consuming. However, you only really need to worry about this at high levels.
- Marketplace prices are inflated...don't be surprised if things are being put up for millions.
- Grind, grind, grind. Grind for your items, gold, gear. It's going to become a nuisance if you don't embrace it.
- Some people insist on having a certain amount of ATT for raids, so you might get kicked from them.
- RNG aint on my side
- You may suffer some lag problems during events or fights.

If you can look past all the faults this game has, then I assure that you will find a great game with combat unlike any other MMORPG I have seen. Just remember to take a break sometimes.

reviewText: This is a good time to voice my opinion about this game, playing since release. So far this game has a very slow and long update for the next new thing. This game has so far improved bits by bits over the years and i say, after season 3 comes out, everything will totally be easy for those who aren't hardcore. This is a great time to get started as doing raids, or solo, is much easier. Do not fret from being kicked from a boat if u need a quest done, simply go easy mode, which was just added, just to complete your quest without the need to find or wait for a raid. Leveling will still be a stingy part of the game so fret forward on that. So far as gameplay goes, the graphics are really nice, combat style is great, there is a good amout of characters to choose from if you don't find your fitting. Only part of the game you will be losing money on is the customization, whether you choose a male to look like Auron, or some other, customlization is a big thing in this game if you wana look cool, or look like a colorful clown, either way, you're going to waste somewhere around 10-15 for the Dazzle'em Dead pack, which is cheaper on steam than in the game. So expect to pay for cosmetics. Honestly this game might not be for everyone, but if you are the casual, expect to easily gain items as you play as it gets easier after Season 3, and also expect to be on a two to three month break of the game, like most people. To me, I will forever play this game as I become the number one Pantsu Fifi, so grind them materals*^*

reviewText:
It's really disapointing, honestly.  The story is nothing to write home about, some of the characters are interesting, the questing is rather dull (and heavily RNG'd on the Side Quests) but my biggest problem in this game comes from the insane difficulty spikes in higher level content.

I'm fine with tough fights.  I love a challenging encounter.  A fight with a boss that can one shot anyone, hit half the arena (and not even as a special attack, that's just one of many) with no possible angle of attack where you can't get annihilated by a random attack with a 0.5 second tell.  God help you if you ever lag.

You can suggest that I'm bad at games if you want, but the real reason for this is actually quite brilliant.  This Nexon game allows you to buy 'Extra Lives', so making the end game raid fights as punishing as possible is 'good' game design.

I love this game's combat system.  It flows nicely, it's entertaining and the animation/sound effects really sells the strength of the hits.  It's only a shame that such a good game was given to Nexon to monitize.  This game system with a better publisher would have been amazing.

As it stands, if you want to romp around and just kill some grunts with a good combat system, it's good for that.  It's almost got a Dynasty Warriors feel to it, depending on the character you pick.  However, when you get to the late game there won't be anything for you but brutally punishing 'Raid' battles that stand between you and continuing the story.  I don't mean one or two, by the way.  The last DOZEN quests of Season 1 contain at least 9 Raids.  Hope you have a lot of friends, or like waiting for people to join your party so you can keep playing the game.

Fun for a quick romp, but look elsewhere if you want anything of substance.

reviewText: If you're tired of WOW hotkey type combat, this is probably the game you're looking for. The combat system alone makes the game worth playing, it's actually a shame you don't see this type of combo system in MMO's very often, as this makes it alot more interesting. It's very addicting, and you'll be spending days late game trying to catch those elusive raid drops. However, as with many Nexon games it survives off of microtransactions, as paying for certain aesthetics and even some game changing items are in the game, this being one of it's major flaws. It IS possible to get through the game without spending a penny, just very difficult.\nThe exp gain rate is okay compared to most MMOs, only getting truly painful up in your 65-80 level range. But by the time you're level 70, getting to 80 isn't always on your mind and it's best to just ease into the level. Overall it's a VERY good game despite it's flaws, yet every game has flaws of it's own.

reviewText: First of all, i come from the beta days. Back when there was only 3 characters and Evie still swung around her staff as a melee weapon (which is funny cause her doppelganger in the labyrinth still does this).  There are now 9 characters, each with very different styles of play, VERY pretty and powerful skills and while it can get a tad repetitive it's still enjoyable. While i do not support Nexon, i support this game. It's pay2lookgood, not pay2win. You can do everything you need to without paying a cent which is what free2play games are supposed to be. Granted progress may be slower than what you could" be getting but that's just how F2P games stay afloat. They take advantage of impatience and what people want which depending on your stance may be a good or bad thing. Regardless

reviewText:
It's technically an MMO, but it plays like a multiplayer action game.

This interesting hybrid of gameplay styles works wonderfully.

In addition, Vindictus is compatible with xbox 360 controllers, and works quite well with them during dungeons. You'll still want a keyboard and mouse handy for the town areas and for typing and UI selections though.

I find it difficult to enjoy most MMO titles, but this one really feels like you're playing an action title. The gameplay is fast paced and action oriented. Dungeons are initially doable solo, but eventually the difficulty ramps up too high for that.

Thankfully, joining random groups is simple and streamlined. Quest and mission objectives are usually very straightforward and areas are fairly linear for the most part, so teaming up and working together with other players is rarely a chore or hassle.

The story is a bit on the weak side, but the gameplay is the star of the show, and it shines brightly.

reviewText: This is a good time to voice my opinion about this game, playing since release. So far this game has a very slow and long update for the next new thing. This game has so far improved bits by bits over the years and i say, after season 3 comes out, everything will totally be easy for those who aren't hardcore. This is a great time to get started as doing raids, or solo, is much easier. Do not fret from being kicked from a boat if u need a quest done, simply go easy mode, which was just added, just to complete your quest without the need to find or wait for a raid. Leveling will still be a stingy part of the game so fret forward on that. So far as gameplay goes, the graphics are really nice, combat style is great, there is a good amout of characters to choose from if you don't find your fitting. Only part of the game you will be losing money on is the customization, whether you choose a male to look like Auron, or some other, customlization is a big thing in this game if you wana look cool, or look like a colorful clown, either way, you're going to waste somewhere around 10-15 for the Dazzle'em Dead pack, which is cheaper on steam than in the game. So expect to pay for cosmetics. Honestly this game might not be for everyone, but if you are the casual, expect to easily gain items as you play as it gets easier after Season 3, and also expect to be on a two to three month break of the game, like most people. To me, I will forever play this game as I become the number one Pantsu Fifi, so grind them materals*^*

reviewText:
Farlander's review is pretty much spot on. I do have to add, though, that the game suffers from awful optimzation and terrible servers.

My system (i7-920, 12GB DDR3, GTX 660) gets 15-45 FPS with many many spikes into unresponsive 0 FPS. There is an option for using multiple processors but it's much like MWO's DX11 option in that it does absolutely nothing. If you host a raid you better have an i7-4790K that's pretty overclocked to get good framerate or any dual core and higher CPU with a frequency over 4GHz. This game is very limited by the CPU and it's clock speed. If you have an i7-4790K and throw a 7800GTX in, the game will run almost as good as if you put a GTX 980. It's that bad. I know, I've tested it.

Resolution: 1920x1080
CPU + GPU - Average FPS - when tested
P4 2.4GHz + 6600 GT - <20 FPS - at release of game
i7-920 + 7800 GTX - ~30 FPS - 3+ years ago
i7-920 + 2x 7800 GTX SLI - 33 FPS - 3+ years ago
i7-920 + 2x GTX 260 SLI - 35 FPS - 2+ years ago
i7-920 + GTX 460 - 40 FPS (see a pattern yet?) - 2 Years ago
i7-920 + GTX 660 - 43 FPS - Today (After a fresh OS reinstall)
i5-2500K + GTX 760 - 50 FPS - Today
i7-4770K + GTX 690 - 60 FPS - 2 years ago (iirc)
i7-4460 + GTX 970 - 60 FPS (seems to be the framelimit even without VSync) - a month ago

Mind you with every single one of these they had <30 FPS if you hosted a large raid. If the CPU has less than 3.2GHz clock speed you go down into the teens with spikes of unresponsiveness. The i7-920+GTX660 was struggling on Lakoria, Glas Ghaibhleann, Thor (especially bad), The Evil One (just unplayable...), and The God of Fomors (full party = 5-10 FPS).

I've played Alpha's of newer games with better optimization.

reviewText:
Pros: Plenty of character customization, combat is good and stylish, Character models and armor look good

Cons: Environments are definitely second to the characters in detail, poor community, gets stale quickly, PvP is a joke, Feels very small in scale due to the fact that there is only lobbies and instances nothing else, story is entirely forgettable, lots of server issues, and P2W




So to explain a bit, I have put a fair amount of time into this game (1000+ hrs) so it is most definitely something i know what im talking about. It has good looking characters with plenty of customization and there really isnt another online game with combat like it, but thats the extent of its good. The game story is completely forgettable and you will be spending most of the time attempting to skip it when speaking with an NPC, voice acting for cut scenes is C grade at a stretch.

The whole lobby/dungeon system and no open world really makes it feel confined and serves to simply diminish the feeling of there being any real content. Youll run the same runs with the same scenery over and over and over and over, itd be one thing if you could explorer a vast and beautiful world but you cant, it doesnt exist outside your small towns. Speaking of the environments they are rather poorly made, they get the job done but in contrast to the characters they look like crap until you get to certain parts of Season 2 but still very dull in appearance and not much life to them.

Once you reach endgame its going to be a 6 month if youre lucky grind but more than likely years of grinding to get endgame gear due to extremely low drop rates which by the time you get it will be outdated anyway. You will be forced to spend money and find less than admirable ways to acquire the gear for you to be considered relevant (lots of P2W in Vindi). On that topic you will also find yourself in a community with a rather heavy elitist attitude to it, many are not newbie friendly and if you dont have endgame gear will get kicked frequently from boats later in the game which increases the difficulty of getting endgame gear even more.

PvP is an absolute joke and was shackled on later in the games life and it shows as there is little reason to actually do it outside of it being forced in order to get certain items. This game has lots of potential, and the combat is great, but nexon has not done anything to really keep the player outside of plenty of TnA. The servers also have lots of issues and you will disconnect and lag ALOT. Once you reach that pinnacle of endgame gear and such there will be nothing left but to chat in lobby 1 and wait for the new raids with the better" gear which wont come till they increase the level cap so there are large expanses with new content but only side grades of gear with different aesthetics."
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this game on and off for several years (since the time they removed the limited boat boarding system), and I have to agree with most of the top reviews: Nexon looks like a ♥♥♥♥ company. Joining Steam has opened up the game to a much bigger and diverse gaming community, and I definitely appreciated the presence of new Steam players hopping on. Here are some pros & cons.


Pros:

+ Excellent artistic style in characters, environment, boss fights, armor, and [most] cash shop outfits.
+ Incredible boss fight music
+ Thrilling gameplay that involves maneuvering around boss movements. [My FAVORITE aspect of this game!]
+ Break off system that gives boss hunting a new meaning
+ Very unique differences between each starting character's play style
+ Breaking armor and revealing [cash-purchased] inner armor is mucho sexy.
+ Community still has very nice people near the start of the game. Just very hard to find.
+ Paladin & Dark Knight transformations are very epic to pull out in times of need.
+ Dynamic environment - Barrels, crates, and other things break when struck or thrown.
+ Erotic inner armor designs. (Con: They all cost money to permanently own.)
+ Coloring armors and outfits. (Con: Costs money, again... & many people just make their armors look ridiculous with neon bright colors that step out of the game's original art style.)
+ In-game marketplace is very dynamic (Con: takes weeks of waiting on selling at highs and buying at lows = ridiculous amount of time investment)
+ Nice movesets and combos that give different methods of versatility during combat.


Cons:

- They released a Sword Art Online Kirito outfit that still has a bug with the coat flapping and humping your leg. People who paid $35 for this outfit can't even put this thing on due to comments from other players. It seems that they are planning on moving on and ignoring this issue. (FINALLY fixed after more than a year!*)
- Plenty of elitists.
- Very buggy game. Lots of issues. Not very stable.
- Lag becomes a big issue when timing precise and accurate dodge mechanics. The system does not give you the benefit of the doubt when you've begin a dodge but computer skips several frames of it.
- Enhancement & Enchanting systems are batshit silly. Don't even try it. (see other reviews)
- Outfit and armor appendages clip through the insides a lot, but may not irritate some players.
- Someone is always looking at your equipment to make sure they are better than you. Then they act very happy on boats when they see that they've got no competition in racking up damage dealt to the boss. (Results screen reveals this)
- Paladin & Dark Knight path levels take forever to level up. It becomes dismissed when a player finds out how much time it requires to reach the 2nd transformation.
- Event exclusive items are mostly, if not all, timed crap. No joy in getting them.
- When dying or coloring things in the Avatar shop, the light does NOT match the actual environment. Very possible to select an offset color that only looks good under strong light.
- Community is filled with many naive people. Immature. Often sides with guild members and friends in ganging up and bullying other players.
- Players who have been treated unfairly by Nexon customer service and pathetic compensation are left to fade away with no recognition of the event by other players.
- The server screws everyone when an event attracts waves of Vindictus players to come back. Especially the quest dialogue reveals that it has a loading time. (Seriously... this is such an inefficient way of processing game information.)
- Very limited end game armor options. All end game armors cost too much money and are excluded to only those that can grind enough money to get it. (again, ridiculous time investment that does not reward actual amount of time spent. depends on RNG -- with very low odds of getting rare drops)
- There's even a site called vindictussnobs.something -- Highly invested players know that they are snobs? Okay.
- ... This can keep going. The cons are abysmal as long as player satisfaction remains negative.


I could go on all day talking about the Pros and Cons of the game; however, I hope this gives good info for what players will possibly deal with when picking this game up. It's one of those games that I can only play with a single friend or two. It is definitely not a game I can recommend to most people. Nexon's finance model is truly reflected in all of their hosted games. I can only continue to play this game by myself (and sometimes with a friend) because it is ultimately a very lonely experience for someone who is casual but still loves certain parts of this game.

After reading a few of the top reviews: Hiding armors and other enjoyable features for cash shop promotions? Seriously? What a way to sink a company's reputation.

reviewText:
(This review comes from an experienced player wih multiple lvl60+ characters, most of my time with the game (and a lot of the actual enjoyment I got from the game) coming from before the game was released on steam)

Used to be a fun hack and slash mmorpg, one of the very few. It is still fun on the surface, but end game is massively pay2win and ultimately just not fun.

You'll see hundreds of reviews here saying mostly the same thing, but let me tell you about Nexon instead.

Nexon does not give a ♥♥♥♥ about you or me, only money. They don't care about customer service, and tickets have taken up to a month to get a response in my own experience. They ignore all feedback their playerbase gives and somehow end up breaking the game more with each patch.

Nexon do not deserve your time, bandwith, or money. Jump into vindictus if you want a few hours of fun, but it will get stale fast, and do not give them your money.

If Vindictus was made by a different company with better business practices, I might be singing a different tune.

reviewText:
It's really disapointing, honestly.  The story is nothing to write home about, some of the characters are interesting, the questing is rather dull (and heavily RNG'd on the Side Quests) but my biggest problem in this game comes from the insane difficulty spikes in higher level content.

I'm fine with tough fights.  I love a challenging encounter.  A fight with a boss that can one shot anyone, hit half the arena (and not even as a special attack, that's just one of many) with no possible angle of attack where you can't get annihilated by a random attack with a 0.5 second tell.  God help you if you ever lag.

You can suggest that I'm bad at games if you want, but the real reason for this is actually quite brilliant.  This Nexon game allows you to buy 'Extra Lives', so making the end game raid fights as punishing as possible is 'good' game design.

I love this game's combat system.  It flows nicely, it's entertaining and the animation/sound effects really sells the strength of the hits.  It's only a shame that such a good game was given to Nexon to monitize.  This game system with a better publisher would have been amazing.

As it stands, if you want to romp around and just kill some grunts with a good combat system, it's good for that.  It's almost got a Dynasty Warriors feel to it, depending on the character you pick.  However, when you get to the late game there won't be anything for you but brutally punishing 'Raid' battles that stand between you and continuing the story.  I don't mean one or two, by the way.  The last DOZEN quests of Season 1 contain at least 9 Raids.  Hope you have a lot of friends, or like waiting for people to join your party so you can keep playing the game.

Fun for a quick romp, but look elsewhere if you want anything of substance.

reviewText:
This is an MMO with most of the standard stuff... Cash shop (not pay2win), grind walls, lots of people, nice guys, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bags, and all of the rest in between. BUT this game comes with the BEST action combat I've ever played! There are games I've payed for that don't come close to this level of awesome.

The graphics are actually really good for a game with Dx9 and built on the source engine. The bosses are creative and sometimes irritatingly difficult (but then you just bring a bud and wipe the floor with'em).

PvP? Couldn't tell ya how it is because I don't like to fight people on games like this... so I don't and it doesn't hinder the gaming experience on bit.

The music is good too and gets you pumped for fights

Then there are the wide variety of classes to choose from. At the moment there is a character for nearly every playstyle. The only one they don't have is one that uses stealth as their primary form of defence.

The only down side I see to this game is the RNG is aweful and can ruin your character by destroying the only weapon you own and leaving you with no money left. You sometimes have to have extreme luck for that NOT to happen. Good thing about that is you only have to worry about it during the late end game stuff.

reviewText:
Tired of falling asleep while playing your favorite MMO? Craving action packed combat? Tired of kill ten rats and bread crumb quests? PLAY THIS GAME! Each character comes equipped with dozens of awesome attack skill combos that continue to give me warm fuzzy feelings of epic awesomeness every time I use them.

I recommend you don't go into this game expecting an MMO, though, because it's really more of an epic co-op monster-fighting game of awesomeness... With awesome epicness.

Also, Nexon is a horrible, horrible company that is doing everything in its power to make this game unfun. But if you can ignore the cash shop, ignore the uninspired special events and ignore your inability to progress through the leveling grind and the gear grind (as a result of ignoring the cash shop), you can actually enjoy this game for what it should have been and still kind of is under all the Nexon-crap, that being, a really fun and extremely epic action-combat monster-pummeling boss-battling epic fighting game of epicness!

reviewText:
Vindictus is a very fun game but you need to be prepared for what you are getting yourself into.  This is an action MMO and probably the best of its kind.  There is no real world to explore and not a whole lot to do outside of dungeon crawling.  Also, be prepared for a very heavy grind and long farming sessions.  Also the company that runs the game kind of blows.  Also, the community is just so-so.  There are a lot of elitists in this game.  A lot.

But the game itself really isn't terrible at all and if you're a fan of Blade & Soul, Tera or any other action MMO you'll feel right at home.  But keep in mind that this game is very challenging and if you want to do any of the higher end-game content, you'll either have to spend hundreds of dollars in the cash shop or farm til your eyes bleed.  The amount of customization is great in this game and you can make your character look amazing, but again, it all comes down to how much money you want to throw into the cash shop.

The game isn't pay-to-win, however, and there's plenty of opportunity for glory to those who work hard enough.  Just enjoy the ride and find a nice guild to call home.  Know what you're getting into ahead of time and there won't be any surprises.
