reviewText:
Product received for free

Quick Summary: Vindictus for PVE grinding only. Classes are imbalanced and heavily gear dependent in PVP. Grinding involves RNG drops, meaning that you might have to do an instance many times to get what you want. Enchantment system is pure RNG, with chance to downgrade your enchancement level once you go past +10. Cash Shop items can prevent this. Endgame PVE revolves around Raids, where you have to get meet certain DPS benchmarks to even be considered for boats.

Did i also mention overpriced cosmetics and pervy underwear?

Lag and recent Optimization quirks will make you rage sometime.

WTB Lynn buffs.

In the meantime I'm heading off to play Black Desert Online which is like the Sandplot MMO version of Vindictus only without (p2W) enchancement cash shop items and with an added addition of Open World pvp and GvG.

reviewText: The game's model promotes investing cash into gear to stay ahead of the curve just to meet requirements needed to even beat the content. Attack vs skill had more of a balance in the long ago past but the scale definitely favours your stats these days. The bosses have become closer to punching bags than enemies with little fulfillment outside the worthless e-peen of damage rankings in end results.\n\nI will still recommend it if you find a nice group of friends to play with since the game can also be a good social experience within guilds. And while it's harder to play casually, the option is still there (might get kicked for low stats). It will depend on what type of person you are and what you want. My funnest times were yelling at random people while wearing shorts and a bunny hat, and that's a successful casual experience in my book. Maybe yours will be to have powerful gear for your battles, but try not to get too caught up in it.

reviewText: This game took my MMO virginity. I can feel my life slowly falling into an abyss. It got me thinking into the future of gaming. A future where there was no distinction between multiplayer and single player. There would just be a game, a world. Worlds that would be entered and stories told within them. Rather dramatic honestly. Being 'online' would not be unlike the contrast of being in the city and living in the suburbs. Like a city wide wireless connection. It also got me thinking into the viablity of free-to-play games. It's not just a design change or even a mechanical one for the end user. It's a whole paradigm shift. It's like you go to inhabit a world that exists regardless of your presence. Like a store front that looks nice in all but wouldn't sell anything if they didn't let you in without making a promise to buy something or even have a entrance fee before allowing you to browse the wares. Maybe I read into things too much.. more rpg's need active dodges like this. I hate queueing up actions for a behind the scenes turn style thing. If your doing a turn based game be up front about it. Same goes for action. They shouldn't blend. It's weird.

reviewText: I've spent almost 6 hours just trying to get this game to run. As soon as I fixed one launching error, another would pop up. I reinstalled the game twice and even after I had checked the file integrity immediatly after installing, it said there were issues. So I had to go through the game's files and delete random .avi files and rewrite dates in text files to be current. After finally getting into the main menu and excited to start playing, I can't even connect to a server. I tried all of the whopping 3 servers to try to play and none worked. The game looks fun to mess about with until you get to the endgame grind, but with the overwhelming amount of flaws with just launching and entering the game, coupled with many other people's frustrations with customer service (which you will be bound to run in to eventually) and game design revolving around in-game purchases, I can't recommend it in the least.

reviewText:
This should be avoided for some basic reasons.

1) No 4K support, yet the game is available in 2015.   When they stop supporting modern PCs, they should stop trying to spruik the game
2) Microtransactions everywhere - including hair colour and hair style, require you to give the developer money for doing a half arsed job of writing a game
3) Microtransactions rammed down your throat during every loading screen
4) Long winded, hard to skip, mediocre story chunks force fed to you while you mash buttons trying to skip the horrors of a game locked to 1080p and lower resolutions (Did I mention it was 2015?)
5) The game itself brings nothing new - the graphics are terrible because you can't even run at any res better than 1080p,  poorly optimised, and no interesting gameplay elements over the competition.

Don't touch this one.  There's older free MMOs that support contemporary PC specifications, and somehow manage at the same time to keep thier hands out of your wallets rifling for DLC money.   Seriously these guys come across like street beggars asking for money because they pushed out a game that wouldn't sell enough copies if it was Pay2Play, so they had to resort to panhandling.

reviewText:
The game is great.  I love the fast action reaction based gameplay, very fun.
However..
The game is unplayable with lag ~20-30% of the time.
It's blatently obvious why too - hackers.
Hackers and botters.
Botting hackers.

Check the god damned boats, naked lvl 30+ lanns insta-killing teleporting speedhacking on every boat.
I've reported it several times, uploaded two videos of it on youtube.
One copy-paste response from support.

Do not support this game, bail now or don't start playing.
Economy and server stability are both dominated by the botting hackers, ruins the game.
I'd say it's not that bad, and in my opinion.. botters actually help the market for new players because it makes things available at a lower price.  But it ♥♥♥♥s higher level players in terms of farming, and it ♥♥♥♥♥ all over the chest of the server stability.

How does nexon not have better detection/prevention?
I mean I know there's bots in like.. world of warcraft right?  I imagine every game could have a bot designed for it, with minimal detection risk by adding non 100% optimal pathing, randomized routes etc etc to make it look human.
But blatant insane hacking letting you one shot kill ANYTHING while naked?  Speed hacking?
These things shouldn't be in the game first of all.. secondly they should be EXTREMELY easy to detect and ban the accounts/IPs.

Wtf Nexon.

reviewText:
I don't usually do pros and cons, but I think the format will work well for this review, so here it is.

Pros:
- Excellent combat. It feels like an action game, everything is synced well between players, there's even physics-objects to smash to bits and throw your enemies into. This is what MMOs should be doing.
- Large number of characters to try with varying fighting styles. You'll probably find one you like if you try them all.

Cons:
- High difficulty. If you want to win, you will have to try HARD, and very likely get some friends to help you with the harder levels. Oh, and do not expect to solo late-game bosses. Ever.
- If you're not interested in story (like me) there's a lot of dialogue to skip through, which can be annoying.
- It gets grindy once you hit the wall that is level 60.
- You will probably have to pay some real money to make your character look pretty.
- Nexon. Need I say more?

I know it looks like the cons outweigh the pros in this case, but keep this in mind: even if the game gets grindy, even if the difficulty is high, even if there's annoying quest dialogue, the base gameplay is FUN. Fun enough to make the game worth playing, at least in my opinion.

tl;dr - It's not perfect, not by a longshot - but the combat is the best I've seen in an MMO. Worth giving a try.

reviewText:
Rare that you will find an MMO that plays remotely simmilar to this. Controls and Feels like Dynasty Warriors. Great to play in co-op with freinds.

Beware of a few things: it uses a Class System with limited character customisation. You will have to leap past an initial pay-wall and buy a dazzel-em dead pack if you want a fully customized character. In fact just straight up beware of all the DLC, it's a free to play game and DLC costs a boatload, and much of  the actually useful stuff is upright temporary.

And Also beware of the fact that the game's graphical, lighting, and gameplay quality will amp up as you progress through the game, and won't really begin to shine until halfway through season 1 of the game when you enter Rocheste. Nearly all the gameplay balances came in the form of Character updates, and the early levels have not been overhauled yet (but apparently character and armor textures are about to be updated to higher res, so you have something to look forwards to).

Otherwise, it's a great game that is worth a shot. And might just help tide you over till Black Dessert comes out.

First off: If you're looking for a F2P MMO that you don't want to put money into: Turn away. Right now.

The game itself is fun when you're playing with a group of friends and helping eachother out.

The gameplay is very fun, open combat" (no targeting

reviewText:
This game is fun, at first, but you need to understand this game is pay to play (not pay to win).

So for starters.

This game is fantastic at the start, your char and moves feel great and monster and environments are interesting. However, as you get to endgame the game violently shifts to pay to live...  Meaning, you will have to spend real money on health pots, goddess graces, and other items to keep you alive because if you attempt to to use the free itmes you will get hit, and when you get hit you will lose more hp than you would of gained drinking the potion.

Additionally, you will need a beefy computer and internet connection to host games because this game is Peer to Peer connections ... meaning Lag is an issue.  Combat at endgame is all about twitch combat and if your connection sucks you will be eating the ground before you know it.

There is no function support for this game.  Meaning Nexon the publisher and Devcat the developer both suck at their jobs and do not respond to support tickets.

Endgame hurts ... Ive been paying for years and have only gotten about 10 endgame gear drops ... so you have to grind and sell items on the Market Place to make money to buy the rare drops.

You need stupidly high dps for endgame as bosses have a defense limit you have to break or you will be doing effectivly no dps ... so this leads to elitiest boats.

There is no balance in the game.  I have a Hammer Fiona ... I do stupidly low dps in endgame because thats just how things work now .... I refuse to switch because I love hammers and unless Devcat rebalances the clas or adds new abilities thats the way it goes.

Kai's are OP as all getout ... their mobility and ranged dps means they can avoid most boss spam and continue high dps, so if you are looking for a fun class ... they are your money ticket.

There are in game purchases ... and they are overpiced.


They key to surviving in this game is 2 things... find good friends and a good social guild.... you need to have fun or this game will rub you the wrong way hard.

reviewText:
This game gave me cancer so instead I'll tell you the 10 easy steps you can take to making a traditional tiramisu at home!

Ingredients
3 large eggs
500 grams [~12.3 oz.] Mascarpone cheese
Espresso or Strong Coffee
Boudoir biscuits/ Lady fingers/ thin cakes
(optional) 1 cup of cognac
Powdered cocoa [or instant chocolate drink mix]
Sugar (to taste)

STEP 1 : Crack and make 3 large eggs into two different bowls (use a large bowl for the egg white and a smaller bowl for the yolk). Make sure that none of the yolk gets mixed with the egg white, otherwise the egg whites won't whisk properly.

STEP 2 : Whisk the egg yolks with an electronic whisk and gradually add sugar until the egg yolk becomes thick, creamy, and light yellow.

STEP 3 : Add about 5oo grams [~12.3 oz.] of Mascarpone in another bowl and give it a quick stir to loosen it up. Then, with the electronic whisk, mix the egg yolks and Mascarpone together.

STEP 4 : Wash and dry your whisk and then whisk the egg whites until they form firm peaks. Continue to fold the egg whites into the Mascarpone and mix until there are no lumps.

STEP 5 : Put that to the side. Make some strong espresso and let it cool.

STEP 6 : Line a large and fairly deep dish with lady fingers (boudoir biscuits) and pour over two thirds of the coffee mixture.

STEP 7 : Put half of your egg mixture over the top of that, followed by a thick dusting of cocoa. Use an instant drinking chocolate, as it's a little sweeter.

STEP 8 : Dip more lady fingers into the rest of your coffee mix (don't worry if you run out; you can just knock up some more) and carefully place them over the the top of the cocoa.

STEP 9 : Empty the rest of your egg mixture over that and dust with cocoa again.

STEP 10 : Leave it in your refrigerator for two hours and serve.

Now take the tiramisu out of the fridge and stuff it all into your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, wait 3-4 days for results.

reviewText:
I've played Vindictus since the start of OBT. I've played the game for many hours throughout these few years, and I must say that this game is by far the most addictive game I've ever come across with.

With that said, here are my pros and cons.

Pros:
Hack and Slash - This game is unique in game-play with it's hack and slash mechanics. I have played many hack and slash games, and I can say none of them compete well with Vindictus. It's battle system has kept me playing for years. It's combos gave me a rush of dopamine from the get-go. I got hooked, and it felt good.

Character Diversity - Each character has it's unique play-style. Currently, you can play as 8 characters. Lann, Fiona, Evie, Karok, Kai, Vella, Hurk, Lynn, and soon Arisha. Each character is unique in battle. Even while Vella and Lann share the same weapon (Twin Swords), they feel very much different from one another. I've tried each character, and can see similarities among them, but they stand out on their own.

The Abundance of Channels - Each Server has a total of 200 channels. Whether you want to interact, or play alone, channels provide a spot for everyone.

The Story - The story is beautiful. I will not explain it, I don't like giving story spoilers. I will say, this game would be an amazing anime.

Cons:


RNG - Of course, this will be my first con to list. The RNG (Random Number Generator) of this game is very broken. You want to gear up, and enhance as best as you can?
Gear enhancement can be very, very risky.
After +6, you will risk the enhancement to 0, and after +8, you risk breaking.

Some people have a lot of luck, and could possibly go from +0 to +15 in one go, but that's extremely rare.
A lot of players resort to buying NX to buy Enhancement Runes to protect their arsenal.
Over all, the RNG seems really unfair to everyone.


Drop Rate - This goes along with the RNG. The drop rate sucks in this game, even with VIP, or VVIP services (which range from 10$ to 20$ a month) most of the drops end up being garbage.

Server Stability - (Peer to Peer) - More times than not, I stay away from 24-man raids, and leave boats where the host only has 1 bar. Peer to Peer works great in Korea, but face it... North America is much more vast than South Korea.

Bots - This game is infested with bots. These bots also inflate the economy, making things harder to earn.

Depot Shop/Avatar Shop Pricing - The prices tend to be high up there. Though, you do not have to buy anything from these shops, people prefer to buy to look good, or gear up better. The game can have it's ugly pay2win moments.

Recycled Dungeons - Perilous Ruins, Ruins of Sanctity, and Hilder Forest are the same maps. After a while, everything looks familiar, and dull. Prairie Entrance and Fomorian Base are purposely the same location. (Fobellow Prairie). That includes Ainle, and The Catacombs. (Night time, and Day time)

Community - The community of this game can either be amazingly awesome, or terribly annoying.
It ranges from down to earth people who actually play this game, to sorry people who try to tell you how to play the game, and act like they are a better person than you based on their numbers. Though, this is in every game, it's something one must learn to endure in MMORPGs.



My Rating:

Gameplay: 8/10
Story: 8/10
Server Stability: 5/10
Community: 4/10
Dungeons: 6/10
Premium Shops: 6/10

Overall Rating: 6/10.

NOTE: Despite of my review and rating, I recommend this game. You should try it for yourself before you make any conclusions.

reviewText: I liked this game a lot for a while.   It plays like Dynasty Warriors, which I like.  There are a lot of quests to do and places to be.  BUT there is a strong pay-to-win feel with the cash shop, especially since you will die a lot in later levels.  That is where I do have issues, though; the later content.  The last missions CANNOT be solo'd and in fact require a full party (6 people) to defeat.  Solo players will not be getting far unless they are very skilled or overleveled (which is very easy, since you can buy AP caps in the cash shop and just max out all your skills).  Also, good luck finding people to help in the later missions, as most missions have little inthe way of rewards to encourage people to replay.  All in all, this was fun for a while, but unless you have a friends to play with, you will hit a wall and not progress.\n\nI will still recommend this game for the gameplay and story, but only hardcore players will get the full milage out fo this game.

reviewText: I liked this game a lot for a while.   It plays like Dynasty Warriors, which I like.  There are a lot of quests to do and places to be.  BUT there is a strong pay-to-win feel with the cash shop, especially since you will die a lot in later levels.  That is where I do have issues, though; the later content.  The last missions CANNOT be solo'd and in fact require a full party (6 people) to defeat.  Solo players will not be getting far unless they are very skilled or overleveled (which is very easy, since you can buy AP caps in the cash shop and just max out all your skills).  Also, good luck finding people to help in the later missions, as most missions have little inthe way of rewards to encourage people to replay.  All in all, this was fun for a while, but unless you have a friends to play with, you will hit a wall and not progress.\n\nI will still recommend this game for the gameplay and story, but only hardcore players will get the full milage out fo this game.

reviewText:
Ok, so I just recently got this game on steam, but I've been playing it for over two years now.

This game has some very addicting combat mechanics, which are very fast paced later on in the game. There are many character types to choose from, each offering a different playstyle. Along with great gameplay, this game also offers good graphics, and a somewhat destructable environment which u can take to your advantage during some enemy encounters. With that said however this game does have its drawbacks. The majority of the player base is focused towards the later part of the game, which would be fine, but this leaves those at earlier stages left to fend forthemselves, making progrssion lonely, and boring at times. Once you do get to the later parts of the game you soon realise that attaining certain armor and weapons almost impposible as extremely poor drop rates, and insanely high prices means only a lucky few will aquire said items. But don't be discouraged, because even with deacent gear, and sharpened skills you can still play and enjoy every aspect of this game.

To conclude, this game certainly isnt perfect, however, if you find a good guild and make some new friends, you will have a great time slashing and bashing monesters and look good doing it. The gameplay will keep you coming back, and there will always be more improvements to make to the characters you play.

If your at least curious about this game I highly recomend you try it, you might be pleasantly surprised. I'll see you in there. :)

reviewText: This is a fast pased action mmorpg, far better than anything else out there.  Yes, it may be a dungeon crawler with no open world atm, but don't let that hold you back from experiencing this simply amazing game.  It's combat system is extremely involved, you decide if you get hit or not with your own timing, you decide if you can land that attack in time, not some stupid RNG.  New character classes being released every 6 months, we are at a total of 8, each offering a very unique play style.  Nexon has really setpped it up as of late, greatly improving the game's stability and are becoming very consistant with content updates.  I hope you give this game a try, it's more than worth the download!

reviewText:
Beautiful game. Amazing storyline. Creative monsters. Prelude to my second favorite game made by Nexon.

This game has the most beautiful artwork and concepts of armor I have ever seen. Each character is crafted as their own. While the facial features might be the same for all characters, it really doesn't matter when you can personalize any way you want from skin tone to make-up to even under armor. The characters move so in tune with their weapons nothing seems unnatural.

The storyline is fantastic, especially because this is all a prelude to Nexon's Mabinogi. This game is much more serious than Mabinogi and it certainly gives you a break from the care-free enviroment of it, which is sometimes nice. The storyline I can keep track of pretty well with easy to remember names and (regretably) a very small map with 2 towns, one you are in 90% of the time.

The monsters are your usual monsters, but with a little twist and have such amazing graphics and design to them. Gnolls are transformed and given clever names, ranks, titles and even abilities and stray from your usual dog-man creature. Nexon really nailed it on this one when it comes to 3D monster art.

As I said before, this game leads up to Nexon's Mabinogi (which is another great game by them). This clears up some of the plot to Mabinogi and this is all around a good plot on it's own.

This game is absolutely perfect for a gamer who loves running dungeons with an amazing looking character. If you aren't downloading this now, you should.

reviewText:
Beautiful game. Amazing storyline. Creative monsters. Prelude to my second favorite game made by Nexon.

This game has the most beautiful artwork and concepts of armor I have ever seen. Each character is crafted as their own. While the facial features might be the same for all characters, it really doesn't matter when you can personalize any way you want from skin tone to make-up to even under armor. The characters move so in tune with their weapons nothing seems unnatural.

The storyline is fantastic, especially because this is all a prelude to Nexon's Mabinogi. This game is much more serious than Mabinogi and it certainly gives you a break from the care-free enviroment of it, which is sometimes nice. The storyline I can keep track of pretty well with easy to remember names and (regretably) a very small map with 2 towns, one you are in 90% of the time.

The monsters are your usual monsters, but with a little twist and have such amazing graphics and design to them. Gnolls are transformed and given clever names, ranks, titles and even abilities and stray from your usual dog-man creature. Nexon really nailed it on this one when it comes to 3D monster art.

As I said before, this game leads up to Nexon's Mabinogi (which is another great game by them). This clears up some of the plot to Mabinogi and this is all around a good plot on it's own.

This game is absolutely perfect for a gamer who loves running dungeons with an amazing looking character. If you aren't downloading this now, you should.

reviewText:
Of all the free to play games that one can get, this is probably one that you should avoid. Why you may ask? Well because Nexon wants to hoard every last cent you have. For something like a simple full skill reset, which should be free like in various other F2P titles, will cost you $20 (don't even get my started on single skill resets). Vindictus may have really good customisation, but doing so will put a hole through your wallet. $20 for an outfit, $10 for underwear, $8 to colour your gear, and numerous packs that can cost up to $20. That's $58 just to fully customise ONE character.

This game is also very grindy and repetitive. The first two zones are mind-numbingly boring with minimal challenge or interesting combat mechanics. While the combat can be fun at first, figuring out all the combos you can pull off, it becomes a mindless click-fest soon after as you hack and hack and hack and hack and slash your way through paper mache models. You can use the environment to occaisionally help you e.g. objects, but it is ineffective compared to your click spam. There isn't much else you can do apart from the limited number of skills bound to your character. Levelling all your abilities takes a very long time since the points you use to level up are usually rewarded from 20-50 ability points. This may seem like a lot, but when you have about 16 skills that requires 350 each, you're going to need to do massive amounts of farming.

One last thing, if you enjoy multiplayer, this game will leave a sour taste in your mouth since lobbies are hosted by players a.k.a extreme lag 99% of the time

voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted to like Vindictus, I really wanted to but so much holds it back from being a game I can recommend to somebody to play. The game at first glance is gorgeous, fun, and has a community that is helpful as you encounter a large # of players that will join your parties as you tread through Vindictus.

However then you encounter issues, the game first off is poorly balanced and will kill the player when its not his/her fault 5/10 I can garuntee you this. Not only does the game encounter large and randomized lag spikes but the game is poorly taken care of, many glitches since launch still remains. Imagine you want to use a potion and you are in crictical condition so you will need to do this quickly, once you use the potion you freeze for 4 - 10 seconds which may very well cause you to die.

Not only this but the game is P2W as heck, the game forces you to purchase 95% of the customization which it really doesn't have much of in the game. Not only that, but items are overpriced, you might as well buy some PS4 games with the money you spend on this garbage.
Once you have reached lv60, yeah...welcome to hell folks, cause you want to upgrade your gear right? WRONG!!! You upgrade your gear with a fail chance, that's right IT CAN FAIL not only that but if you think you would be ok with just that, nope...they break.

Enchant Scrolls Expire, Random Lag Spikes, Game not taken care of, Nexon's overpriced pixels, breakable items, fail rates upon upgrade methods, gold buyers, botting to the max, P2W system, No customization options without $$$, and Nexon has the balls to not even reply back to a fan who literally wants the best for the game.

So what did we learn today? Vindictus is a poor excuse for a game it could have been, now its turned into junk (I want to say **** but I won't).

My score: 3/10
Cons ---------
Enchant Scroll Expirations
Random Lag Spikes
Bots
Gold Buyers
Overpriced nx items
No free customization
P2W Game
Item Destruction
Upgrade fails
Horrible customer support
nx shop sucks anyways
No grinding allowed (Ban waves)
No farming allowed (Ban waves) (Raids can only be done once a day)
Ban Flags to anyone doesn't matter who the **** you are


Pros--------------
Graphics
Combat

Final Thoughts......
This game is junk, garbage, $^*+, Trash, Booty, Crap, Balls, etc
Keep your money, and if you do play this game, play it until Phantasy Star Online 2, Blade & Soul, Black Desert, Black Sheep, Bless Online, and the real MMOs release. Even Kingdom Fire's combat is a better trade off than this garbo.
Find another game. Please.

reviewText:
Please note: As it may say 0.5 hours on my steam account. I played this game through the nexon site. This was way before Vindictus went on steam :3.

I loved this game...when it first came out. It was absolutley amazing. And the community was awesome. Everyone worked as a team. The grinding was was not tedious.THE COMBAT WAS SO AMAZING! Every move was precise and the physics were just out standing.  .And I say this because every battle was different. The crafting was also worth the time. All and all back then...I would have giving it a 9/10.

Fast Forward today.

No, I can not reccomend this game. I decided to get back into it and see whats changed. And to be honest...it sucks.
I got spammed with bots and people weren't very nice anymore. NO one worked as a team in my experience.
This game had a lot of potential. And I feel like some of it..isnt there anymore. Combat is still decent. But what annoys me is the damage indicators... That really annoys me. Because before. You hit an enemy and it's like.. Damn, I must've hit him hard. And made you wanna hit this enemy more. Now with damage indicators its like... 20 damage... Well damn. I dont feel that immersed anymore. And the list goes on and on.

MY verdict...

You can play this game. But...In my opinion, its not really worth the time and effort

reviewText:
It's basically a hack and slash in the source engine. Sounds fun, but fails in a lot of areas.

+Nice Graphics
+Decent Combat Controls
+Easy to learn combos

-No real LODs for models. Instead everyone on the server looks like they're wear monk robes while they load for some reason.
-Terrible, semi-unskippable text dialogue everywhere.
-Little to no weapon variety. Your character usually has 1-2 weapon types they can ever use. Every weapon of that type is only an upgrade to the last, with no specialized versions.
-Character customization is insanely overpriced. $30 for digital clothes alone.
-You rent in game items for real money when you can't afford the permanent versions. Even when renting the prices are rarely under $7 for a week.
-Ads for you to purchase in-game items everywhere.
-Absolutely no exploration at all. You never really get to go anywhere. Just tiny town with 4 buildings, to a boat, to a series of rooms where you hit things until they die.
-Assets are overused for enemies and levels, making the whole thing feel very lazily made.

The only reason I play this is because I can't get my friends to play anything else yet.

reviewText:
I reached a point where I find myself looking to the free-to-play mmo's for a source of entertainment. This is how I came across Vindictus.
It's looks like it should be a fine, top of the line mmo; but with one flaw that breaks the game before the player actually starts. It was made by Nexon.
Yes, the same Nexon that made the buggy as hell, hacker-infested Combat Arms.
I decided to move past this, thinking Nexon got their act together, and decided to try the game for myself. I installed the game, and was met by not one, but seven launcher crashes in a row. On attempt number eight., I was faced with a long-♥♥♥ background instalation that made me think the game crashed again. Attempt number nine actually got me into the game, but as I tried to connect to the server, the game crashed entirely. Three more attempts just to get into the game resulted in the same crash. Hell, even a personal friend with a recently updated PC even crashed as much as I did trying to get in.
Take my word for it, the game is not worth the amount of time it will take just to start the bloody launcher.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great game, I love it!  Vindictus is very well balanced, and not even slightly pay-to-win.  Though the economy is a bit difficult to wrap your brain around at first, but just take a look at a guide or two and it's easy as pie to get LOTS of money REALLY fast.
Gameplay is simple, yet satisfying in a way; though you will have to go on the occasional grind for mission completion.  Good leveling system and unique skills to unlock, it's really easy to figure out and play.  I'd definitely encourage anyone to play this game!

Edit:  It has come to my attention that I am not nearly as experienced enough in this game as I thought I was.  The above description really only applies until some of the later levels (about lvl 60), and the economy begins to  crash on you:  weapons and equipment are over priced, not enough people are selling/buying resources to craft higher level equipment for cheaper, way too much grinding, and whatnot until you have to result to using real money to progress through the game.

Basically, this game is only worth playing if you like grinding and probably giving up later in the game.  Fun at first, not so much later.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I used to play Vindictus a lot and it is a lot of fun. My sorceress was purely support before they redid how healers function and they added so much to the kit to make the combat aspect fun and engaging. Unfortunately the customer service is abyssmal with and I found myself hacked and in need of assistance. So I submitted a ticket for assitance and a GM was back to me within the hour and I collected all the relevant logs and details they requested and was left with a promise that the issue would be resolved and I would be back kicking gnoll butt in no time.
1 day...2 day...3 day...posted to the ticket asking for a follow up with no response...
1 week...2 weeks...3 weeks...posted again as the issue was still not resolved...
1 month...2 months...6 months...Vindictus is released on Steam but issue still not resolved and poked the ticket...
8 months...9 months...1 year and 1 month later there is activity!
A GM messages me to ask if this open ticket has been resolved yet.
A quick check and I response that it has not. I'm told they'll get RIGHT on it...
13 months...15 months...1 year 6 months later another GM messages me that they have seen no activity for the past year and I respond that I was told to wait for the ticket to be resolved before I resume playing.
I then get a message that no suspicious activity was noted for the past year to indicate the account has been hacked.
I respond back that the ticket is older than 1 year old and all the relevant logs and details requested by the original GM are already part of the ticket.
I get a response that as no evidence of the ticket being hacked within the past year was discovered the ticket has been closed and marked resolved.

So...NEXON customer service. Promise results...wait until they can't fix anything...call the issue closed without solving a thing.

NEVER EVER GOING BACK.

reviewText:
Wow, I remember this one from years ago.  It has one of the most fully-developed physics engines of any MMO I've ever seen.  The four characters (I remember when it was only three, and it may be five soon) all played very differently and honestly, the only one I couldn't really get into playing was Lann (the dual swordsman).  Lastly, a very good story for an MMO.

I feel that its only major flaw is that it's of the hub-and-mission style of MMOs - probably done so they can ensure the physics engine is handled correctly.  However, that flaw is tremendous in a scenario where the 'hub' is an actual area where the players gather, because the lag gets horrendous.

Unfortunately this is one of those games that's marred by the company that holds it - Nexon.  Nexon has NO idea how to deal with any kind of customer support and is notorious for pay-to-win problems.  The latter doesn't actually rear its head NEARLY as much as it did in DFO, but there are still shades of it.

Overall, my bad experiences with Nexon are the main thing preventing me from recommending this.

reviewText:
Unless you like playing a single player game with an MMO grind, I would not recommend this to anyone who likes games for the community.

Vindictus' Achilles' heel is its match-making system. This game is a lobby game that provides a market, PVE, and PVP, yet you can't join other people's PVE stages in-session like Warframe and you're not even allowed to do something productive as your PVE party forms like in Dungeon Fighter Online. In Vindictus, as you form your party, you are confined in an instanced area that provides nothing productive other than a punching dummy, a general vendor, and a mailbox. You end up getting people who don't want to form parties hence people who can't get parties.

For comparision, imagine being forced to do nothing in WoW as you queue up: you can't work on professions, browse the auction house, go do other quests, or even travel. How often would the WoW's community queue with such an absurd confinement?

Warframe was pretty shallow when I played it and DFO Internaltional was shutdown, yet they at least didn't waste your time as you queued for parties.

reviewText:
A surprisingly fun game. Fully active combat keeps the game interesting. Quick slots are only used for healing and other utilities. Works with a gamepad as well as keyboard and mouse.
Graphics are very good.
Levels are very repetitive, you will need to do each level several times.

As usual, Nexon prices are crazy high, 5 dollars for a custom hair cut, 9 dollars for a pet, 2 dollars for pet food, and it gets worse from here.  I suggest this game only as a free game.

Only east and west servers are available, and it does not recommend one to you.  Central players are left in the dark guessing which server to use.

reviewText:
I have never been sold on ANY MMOs, until this one... A friend of mine suggested it to me and I installed it expecting it to be a PAY 2 WIN mess... When I started it up, I was surprised that there was NO launcher, and an actual TITLE SCREEN! A TITLE SCREEN ON A FREE TO PLAY GAME! WHAT? THATS CRAZ- anyways, yes, the game has a title screen. I began to play and after a while I began to notice the extreme lack of money grabbing ♥♥♥♥ other FREE 2 PLAY games tend to throw at you. Ive played for about 5 hours and have only seen two offers to buy things with real money, and that was on a whole different page within a page. I honestly think this could be one of my favorite free to play games that Ive played in a while.

Overall, a very good and challenging game.

For a free to play, worth it.

- Hey, this is an edit... about two minutes after I finished typing all of that.

What makes this game good? Ill tell yah~

One: Very little screen clutter (you know, all that ♥♥♥♥ most MMOs have, yah, this game has little to none at some points)
Two: ITS NOT PAY TO WIN - Rejoice!
Three: If I said it's good, and its an MMO, it must be good... (You know it, JARVIS.)

reviewText: I played this game before it was even on steam. This game takes aspects from two of my favorite genres. It has skills and classes from a typical MMORPG, but then in the combat it takes on aspects of a live-action MOBA (non-rts) style. I would highly recommend this to both casual and hardcore gamers due to its high  potential and tactics when fighting harder enemies. The beginning of the games is slow though, enemies are easy, no one has any troubles, and typically it feels like a grind-fest. However once you get further in the game and get a more in depth touch, you really get engaged in the fast paced, high action, and VERY difficult boss fights.

reviewText:
You may not play it all night long- or then again, you might- none-the-less, this is a fun game to get in and get out.
not super challenging, but the game will make you work for your wins- learn boss patterns or watch as your armor gets torn and broken during your struggle. surrounding scenery is not safe from your devestation, as you watch walls and huts come down around your battles you may even find some secrets!

Free to play, (and yet, not pay to win!)
game is a cross between an action rpg like God of War, and something like Monster Hunter.

TIP!
Get used to the market! it's very straight forward, and user friendly. sell everything you find! especially those ergs and magic powders! then buy all the gear you need!- you'll spend much less money and time- and you won't have to grind."

reviewText: I don't normally like ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes because of how the games usually play, but this plays very fluidly, and it feels like I'm playing God of War, but with help. There are some things that I find odd, like the fact that you can only gain gold from completing missions on hero difficulty, but the game seems to only let me play them on hard or normal. I can get around that, however. Just gather up some blessed powder and sell it to other players on the marketplace and soon you'll be rolling in dough. It's free to play, obviously, so nothing to lose in checking it out...which I recommend.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The story was mildly intriguing, but it was disappointing that I did not get to fight side-by-side with any of the important NPCs. Instead, the reality of this world is left to be told via text and unanimated 2D pictures of the NPCs. And the dialogue is not good enough to jump off the screen on its own.

The combat mechanics are tolerable, but the difficulty was laughably easy. However, it was not the lack of difficulty that annoyed me most about the dungeons but the bland, monotonous layouts of the environments -- and every dungeon is a single, closed path. There is no heart nor soul to the world, and it all feels impersonal and empty.

But, I did have a little fun regardless of all the boringness. I've just no interest in continuing to play it further.

reviewText: Vindictus is a fun game, but sadly its deteriorated into a pay2win game with horrible customer service. The game has been steadily losing population for the last year and Nexon doesn't feel like fixing the game since that doesn't bring in money. They are more focused on releasing Inner Armor for the females so people can clothe their waifus in bikinis. There is nothing in the game for low levels and grouping with your peers at low levels is basically non existant. What end game they have is a grind fest, and by that I mean it takes weeks to get a certain piece you need to improve your gear, and there is a good chance you will lose that piece of gear in the process. Don't waste your time, stay away from this game.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fun until you realize that for a game that been running for about 4 years, it is still plagued by lag and sub-standard customer service and support.

Combat is unique but only after the first couple of times you will realize that the niche of having to block, dodge and time attacks is trivial.

Community is alright but has a large amount of people that are not friendly to new timers. Guild system is non-existent. It is there but there are no real benefits that adds to gameplay or mechanics.

PVE is the main focus of the game but still has a PVP system thats broken and unfinished. People take PVE in this game seriously so beware.

Just wait for black desert instead of wasting your time with this. Atleast that wont be published by nexon. :)

reviewText:
More boring than it advertises itself to be.
Generally, I've played alot of MMOs and this isn't really that bad. It DOES take alot of grinding though, but not too much. You will get swamped in sidequests if you DARE talk to any npcs outside of your main quest.
Many things in the game aren't told/hinted about, which was kinda of annoying. Nobody wants to spend 20 minutes of wiki reading to realize you need to go to a new town in order to learn how to make weapons, although the stations to craft the weapon are in the first town you go in.
Fluid combat, decent graphics, hefty rewards for staying loyal.
Non-generic bosses (mostly), annoying drop rates, grinding.
XP doesn't come too slowly, which is a good thing.
Every class is arguably balanced.
Overally it's a good game, as long as you're used to grinding.

reviewText:
5/5 stars

Pros:
*Amazing skill-based combat and open world physics
*Great action based playstyle with free and fluid movement
*High end graphics with environmental interaction
*Unique genderlocked characters, each with their own playstyle
*Challenging raids
*Fun missions and few grinds
*Fair cash shop, not pay-to-win in any way

Cons:
*Nexon owns it
*Occasional laggy servers
*Cash shop items are overpriced
*Very few updates which makes it hard to keep players interested
*Feels very repetitive when you reach endgame
*Smaller player base than your typical MMORPG

reviewText:
The story was mildly intriguing, but it was disappointing that I did not get to fight side-by-side with any of the important NPCs. Instead, the reality of this world is left to be told via text and unanimated 2D pictures of the NPCs. And the dialogue is not good enough to jump off the screen on its own.

The combat mechanics are tolerable, but the difficulty was laughably easy. However, it was not the lack of difficulty that annoyed me most about the dungeons but the bland, monotonous layouts of the environments -- and every dungeon is a single, closed path. There is no heart nor soul to the world, and it all feels impersonal and empty.

But, I did have a little fun regardless of all the boringness. I've just no interest in continuing to play it further.

reviewText: A Korean made MMORPG that focuses on free combat movement. Most MMOs I find boring due to the similarities in auto attacking and endless quests that seem to relate little to the storyline. Vindictus is allows the player to appreciate farming and lvling since the characters are controlled by you and the combat is free movement meaning there is no auto aiming. You have to have the skill and practice to fight well. Character customization is fairly good with a good variety of cash items in the game. It is a free game with the options of a cash shop. And for some reason the chests of female characters jiggle to an interesting extent while moving.

reviewText:
Basic:
Type:Hack'Slash
Graphics: Very Nice
Gameplay:Very Fun, and take time to improve skill and learn boss. 3rd person view, with basic combo and depending how you apply them on different boss is really fun.
Char: Each char has a very different playing style and each take time to learn.
Economy: Very, very bad at low levels or for new players. you won't make money until you reach near end game. There some bots and gold selling, but less compare to last year.
Players Base: The player base is low to mid. There is not a lot people playing on lower level maps, unless a new char is released or bots.
Char Looks: it cost real money to change your looks which is understandable to some point. If u play for a while you will get some events that allow you get free item that allow you to customize your look. AP shop can also be use. ( AP are point use to level up skill)
PvP:is near dead, becuase how unbalacne it is but its still fun.
Streamable: yes, but very hard to get views.
P2W: Not at all really, depend on your skill level and how much time you spend on the game to get gold.
Updates:It has good updates and reworks, beasue its is really pouplar in KR.

Drepy:

I would say this game is good for solo players, fun learning the boss and make friends along the way. Nice game to play with a small group of friends to help you out and leveling up with you on lower levels. I would recommend you try to find a good guild that very socail and will to help you out on run. The player base is very poor, even on higher level maps. It is a very good game but it lacking player base. It takes  a lot of hard work and gold to reach end game stats.

NOTE: This game is really HARD to get into if you do not put the effort getting to end game. It easy to put off for 3-6 months and comeback later (most players do). Try getting the starter packs if you are new (free if i remember right)

reviewText:
very hand-holdy MMO, dungeon crawling hack n slash. no pay 2 win like how people say, its just pay for cosmetics and more slots in your inventory and pay to skip the game (VVIP capsules which give more drops from bosses, exp boosts from the depot, etc) immsersive combat and tough raids

ive never experienced a single troll here because i play by myself or with one or two friends, no more no less. no trolls in 16 man raids either (at least i havent seen any)

overall, really good game, very grindy, one of the best in the genre, if you're into throwing away a bunch of hours into MMOs this is for you.

only downsides are the level designs at some points can just be recycled like it will be something like the lower leveled dungeon you played before, just with diff lighting and creatures. pvp is almost entirely dead 24/7 which is such a shame because its so smooth.

to the people complaining about this being pay2win: be glad this isn't spiral knights with the energy system

reviewText: Okay now for the good review while the player count is low at the moment the players that are there tend to be very helpful and nice i haven't met a single jerk yet however this means alot of the players are end game or close so execpt early game solo unless you have friends that play. Also i hear people complaining about the cash shop when is all cosmetic and you never really need to buy anything. they still do events and are adding more classes like delia or rosecrush which is coming out soon. The combat is a hack n slash style which is easy in the begining and requires you to use more skill as the game advances. The story is okay at best and the bosses and raid are very cool especailly if you get past the first season.\n\noverall 8/10

reviewText:
The story and characters are bad bad bad bad bad bad bad. The writing is downright awful and so long-winded that I dreaded every time I finished a story mission because I knew what I would be subjecting myself to when returned to town. No amount of heavy drinking can make me give a single damn about any of these one-dimensional stereotypes and their emotional instabilities.

But seriously. Don't read the story. Just click until it's over. The wellness of your soul is a stake.

If you came for the gameplay, it's pretty decent. Some of the characters are unique enough to be interesting, but the levels are repetitive and clearing the way to a boss is boringly easy. On top of that, the late game feels sloppy and unbalanced. The easiest way around that is to hand Nexon tons of money. They love money.

The final nail in the coffin for me is that the nighmarishly slow server lag over the past few months (Yes. Months.) has rendered this game fairly unplayable. It' too bad that I kind of liked it.

Kind of.

That is impossible here.

reviewText:
It's a mindless killfest with beautiful graphics, fast-paced and fluid gameplay, and is quite a joy to play.
It is however, grindy as all hell and if you ever have a problem, good luck with getting anything worthwhile from Nexon's support, as it's shoddy at the very best.

Played during Beta and  off-and-on since then, and it's in general a fantastic game.
I highly recommend trying it out, at the very least.

reviewText:
In a word, awful.

Graphics - More bad clipping than a hair salon full of trainees. Sluggish like I have never seen. I have a fairly high-end system (i7, dual 980's) but couldn't even play on Normal without the game hesitating and just plain freezing up.

Audio - More skipping than a pre-school class after a candy break. Every time the scene changed, the last sound would repeat for about 10 seconds.

Voice acting sounds like they trained at the William Shatner School of Over-emoting.

Controls - Feels like I am walking through water. Could not get my Logitech gamepad to work. Finally gave up when the game told me for the third time it had to restart because I changed a setting.

reviewText:
It's filled with sexualized female armours, unrefined enemies, and a user interface that's too large and complex for any new user to really wrap their head around without some practice. It's also the only MMO I've seen in which there seems to be too much story. The exposition is pointless and redundant, with multiple characters continuously repeating the same points in a few different sentences when only one would have sufficed. I wish I could get around these things, but that plus the lack of any good female armours that don't expose more of your skin than the base underwear does is just the last nail in the coffin for me.
The game is free, at least.

reviewText:
How the hell did Nexon go from Maplestory to this XD

In all seriousness, its not that bad of a game, there are a few things that prevent it from being amazing (Like many mmo's, its a tad bit p2w, and they made it harder for people who want to get things for free to obtain ingame currency, as gold is only rewarded on the highest difficulty setting, which has to be unlocked).

Other than that, the action is pretty great, and playing as Hurk...well, lets just say I've never felt like I was playing as Guts from Berserk until now. The fact that the game was made using the source engine means that it can run decently on a crappy computer like mine, and the environments are highly interactive with many breakables and throwable objects, which can really make you feel like you're not playing an MMO. A solid 7/10.

reviewText: I've been playing this game for like four years now, and it's still one of my favorite Free-to-Play games on Steam. It's one of the few games out that lets you play through the entire game without paying a cent. It's becoming kind of a shame more people aren't playing it, because it could use the love.\n\nThis game plays pretty much like a hack and slash" game. The combat is probably the greatest thing about this game
date: it smooth and it just works. I'm surprised there isn't a whole lot of other MMOs that use combat like this. There is ten characters right now
recommended: nexon releases a new one every year
hoursPlayed: all of them have there own little play styles that's fun in one aspect or another.\n\nThe game essentially plays like this: You run missions through a linear dungeon

reviewText:
Don't you dare. Do not click install. Don't. DOOOOON'T.

This game. I know this game well. Like how well I know that ♥♥♥♥♥ down the street. Like with that strumpet, I wonder if I'm ploughing her or if she ploughs me. Judging by my super-AIDS i assumed the latter. This game will trick you into thinking it's really fun. Because it is. The combat is fantastic. I love it. But absolutely everything else about this game is God-awful. When you start out, it seems really fun. Then you get to the gear and stat grind. It's so bad. It's so damn bad. Nexon took a gem and tossed into a poop pile. 150 damn exquisite iron ores.

Me and the other warlord of my clan decided to try out vindi again for the sick ♥♥♥ raid bosses, since warframe was being DDOSsed. We are towards the end game now, and holy crap FORGET exquisite iron ore. Most armor sets or weapons require an extraordinary amount of how high level ore. Iron comes from speckled turds in the instanced dungeons. One or two spawn. In season 2, u have a chance at getting lowest tier, second tier, third, or low chance at exquisite ores. Usually second tier drops. It requires 4 third tiers to craft exquisite.
These sets require a total of 150 damn exquisite ores, among 20 count drops from raid bosses that are only dailies. Then their is the horrible enhance and enchant system. It's recommended to get a weapon to plus 8 to be any kind of viable. From +5-+8, the percent of success goes to 50%, to 40%. Failure resets rank to 0 and lowers durability, and takes the stones (more grind) you used. Buuut if u buy nexon cash, you can get runes that prevent those effects upon failure. No way to get nexon in game like Warframe btw. No discounts either. Enchants of a good rank only have 50% to 40% of success, but u can increase that by buying ♥♥♥♥. Failure lowers durability and can break weapon for the good enchants. But guess what, u can buy a rune (nexon obviously) that saves your ♥♥♥. Vindictus' gameplay is ♥♥♥♥ing fantastic, but the system built around it is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and promotes pay2win.
At least you can get the parts for a frame in a day, at least formas and potatoes have NO failure chance, and at least you can get plat and resources BY PLAYING THE DAMN GAME.

reviewText:
I'll try to give a quick summary on Vindictus since I've read a lot of the negative reviews and they're all very correct.

DO NOT READ THE POSITIVE REVIEWS THE NEGATIVE ONES WILL TELL YOU MORE ABOUT THE ACTUAL GAME.

Vindictus is a great game run by a horrible company and it pains me to have played the game since the NA beta and watch Nexon slowly kill it.

You will quickly notice the screenshots and teasers for the game are beautiful and rightfully so. The game is epic. In Korea.

The issue comes in more of the MMO aspects of Vindictus. Notice the DLC for 40 dollars that actually gives you nothing...seriously don't buy it...

Also there are 9 characters, 7 released, and you have 5 character slots for free. It takes a week to delete one of your old characters but don't worry you can buy more character slots for 10 dollars...

It's also pretty sad when one of the worst things Nexon did was banning all the botters. If you play the game for a long time you'll notice the price for your gear getting exponentially higher. I've seen the crazy fluctuations in the player economy since 2010.

I've also seen Nexon slowly drop fun events in favor of sales...10% OFF ON REVIVES!!!

The game can only be enjoyed in two ways. Playing for a few hours or playing for a few hundred hours. There's barely a middle zone for it and that's why there is an overwhelming amount of positive reviews. The first few hours of the game will be some of the best hours you will get out of any video game.

Another thing that comes up is the elitist community. Yes it is pretty elitist and I'm actually part of it. The game is pretty difficult and challenging so it makes sense the community isn't very noob friendly. Try not to take this the wrong the issue is that new players can't establish end game gear because of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ drop rates, infuriating upgrades and difficult gameplay but don't worry just donate to Nexon and you'll be fine. Also don't say skill>gear because Vindictus is actually skill<=gear which is unfortunate because a game like this really shouldn't be like that.

I have established above average end game gear and I am part of the very elitist community. I have to say the end game is actually amazingly fun and once you get to know the community it's great. That said I really can't recommend Vindictus solely because of Nexon. Vindictus is the perfect example of why Nexon is ♥♥♥♥.

That really was as quick of a summary as I could give on Vindictus.

Thanks for reading and don't play Vindictus.

reviewText: I have to be honest. My initial thoughts of this game were pretty negative.  There are some things that I do not like about the game, but the positives far outway the negatives.  I'll start with the negatives. I'm not a fan of the way the story progression is set up. It's like a flashback to an old school RPG before character animations and voice acting was implemented.  I don't like having to read the dialogue from a tiny box next to a portrait of an anime character.  It can be pretty boring... which is why I have almost no idea what the storyline is about. It just doesn't keep my attention, so I end up skipping a lot of the dialogue.  Also, the character customization is extremely basic.  I expected quite a bit more, but was disappointed. It is possible to get better hair cuts, costumes, dyes, and armor, but it will cost you quite a bit of real life money. Needless to say, I'm not interested in paying money for in game underwear.  Lastly, I don't much care for the way the quests are set up.  It's not open world, which is kind of lame, so questing is different in this game. Each battle (this is what the quests/missions are called in game) is like a mini-dungeon that is replayable. It's replayable because each battle has a list of achievement-like side quests.  These reward you with gold and experience when you complete them.  So this is a completionists worst nightmare, or wet dream... I could see an argument for both.  None of the battles are too tough, even on hard mode, to finish alone, but the raids require a little more muscle.  So the positives.  The game looks decent enough. The graphics aren't spectacular, but they did a good job on the characters' looks. Especially the female characters. They look pretty damn great. The female characters' costumes would fit perfectly into every nerdy teenage boy's hentai fantasy.  The combat is pretty cool.  It took a little getting used to initially, but once I got it down, I liked it. It's a little big buggy at times when it comes to the dodging and parrying against enemies, but still a lot of fun. It sort of reminds me of Dynasty Warriors back in the day.  You know, before they made 57 remakes.  Overall, it is a pretty fun game. Definitely worth trying if you're even a little bit interested. Plus, its free. How the hell can you pass up trying a free game?  GET THIS GAME.

reviewText:
First of all, you need a decent computer to be able to enjoy this game, maybe more than decent. Second, the game is Free-to-play!!!

The graphics are wonderful, (even though it's been quite a while since its first release). Gameplay is detailed, deep, sophisticated yet simple enough for any newcomer to easily learn and adjust. The story is pretty interesting, nothing too breath-taking, but a good story nonetheless (Still in progress on my end).

6 different characters to choose from, all gender locked, but each being very unique and specialized for certain gamestyles. Each character has 2 unique classes that doesn't require the player to be limited to choosing one of the two. The player can level up both of the character classes with no penalties whatsoever(aside from spending the gold they earn from quests).

The characters can be easily customized without overdoing the options of what can be done(face/nose/cheeks/chin/etc), but the downside is that the variety of the customizations are limited unless a purchase(with real money) was made to be given access to the extra variety. This doesn't mean the player must do make a purchase, it's simply a choice of how far will the player go to give their character the look" that they are going for. Only the customization variety is limited including equipment color changes

reviewText:
I defintely recommend this game if you like infinite dungeon crawling, epic action-y fighting, and fine tuned character skill development!

Vindictus caught my attention because of it's physics system, as you can pick up objects in your environment and throw them at enemies, or pick up enemies themselves in some cases and throw -them-! Almost everything and anything can be picked up and used as a weapon (no exaggeration there), and in the hands of a capible warrior, even a BROOM becomes the doom of some poor monster! You won't be disappointed in the dungeons themselves, as traversing destructible environments, traps, and finding secret treasures will keep you excited (until you realize that the dungeon batches are pretty much copy-paste) and the enemies know and use this environment to their advantage (archers will shoot the supports to bridges to make you fall, enemies will attack destructible pillars to make them fall on you, etc). The game is made with the Source Engine, so it really hits home how diverse this software can be when used in game development (it surprized me that a company could use the SE like this)!

reviewText:
I’ve been experimenting with the MMO genre lately. Most games I tried would procure a couple hours of fun after which I would quit. The reason for this: I felt like I was wasting my time. Contrarily to popular belief, Video games don’t usually give me that feeling. I needed something better than your typical MMORPG with a failed plot and little replay value. I needed a game that felt... I don’t know, like more than just a game. I found it. If the title didn’t give it away, I’m talking about Vindictus.

Vindictus is an MMO that combines your typical RPG experience with a hack n slash feel, impressive visuals, lush and varied environments, a good story and an insane replay value only to name a few aspects. The community is amazing and the huge 18 player team battles with make this game seem unreal. In short, Vindictus is exactly what I was looking for. Vindictus is more than just a game.

Vindictus runs on Valve’s source engine. Nexon (the studio behind the game) probably picked this engine to allow extreme interaction between the player and the world. Past games like Half-Life 2 and Portal can testify to the awesomeness of this engine. Needless to say Nexon made a great choice. Contrarily to most online multiplayer games, the world behind Vindictus actually feels alive. Picking up, throwing and smashing objects around feels perfect. When I throw a wooden barrel into the ocean, the barrel sinks then resurfaces and floats. IT DOESN’T DISAPPEAR. The physics engine is out of this world.

The story is interesting enough. There are a couple cut scenes coupled with dialogue that may or may not entice you to read more of it. I have to say that the dialogue is actually pretty good and I often find myself wondering what’s going to happen. This is one of the rare aspects that Vindictus does not excel in. Moving on to the online part of the game, it‘s crazy how fun this game is to play with friends. Before starting it, I suggest you find 2 or 3 friends and start it all together, because all 3 of you will have a blast. Everything in this game can be done in teams, and as I said earlier the big team battles against seemingly invincible bosses are something you will be talking about in the morning.

Earlier I mentioned the environments. They’re epic. I mean really epic. You go from fighting vampires in a pillaged town to fighting mummies on desert dunes only to end up with reapers in a dark crypt. Jungles, deserted plains, tropical islands, ancient ruins; this game has it all. The monsters themselves have amazing sprites that could easily be compared to a triple A game such as Skyrim. Each mission ends with a boss fight, usually a great boss fight. Beating bosses is easy once you understand their attack pattern, at least early on. All you Sword Art Online fans will feel right at home, but let’s not get into that.

Now I think it’s time we talk about the combat. There are about 8 different characters in Vindictus, each one having a unique and interesting combat style. Whether you want to shoot from a distance, cast fireballs, or leap into the fray with a giant pillar, there’s a combat style for you. My first character was Vella. A girl that dual wields either swords or chain blades. The former allows you to slice n dice from close range while the latter allows you to rip through enemies from far away. Every character has 2 weapons like this. Considering this, we can safely confirm that you can fight through this game in 16 different ways. I used twin blades with Vella. Once you’ve chosen a weapon. You can unlock abilities both passive and active as you progress through the game. For instance, when you start playing, the shift button activates a dash. Level up enough and you can unlock the Slipaway ability, letting you jump back while cutting anyone around you for some very handsome damage. Double tapping shift will activate this and pressing it a third time will throw in a dash to the combo. Very useful for escapes, making Vella an agile fighter if need be (extremely useful against bosses). Other abilities, such as Cross Cut will let you run right through an enemy attack if timed perfectly.

Character customization is always important in an RPG. Vindictus once again makes me drool with insane skins and armour, making this dark themed, possibly depressing concept into something quite enjoyable to look at. This being said, many decorative aspects of the game require that you pay, but its player versus monster nature makes these things not an issue.

There is PVP, although you will have to play for a while before experiencing it. All I can say for now is that I have noticed a rock paper scissor effect between certain characters. If you’re looking for a PVP heavy game, Vindictus is not what you’re looking for.

Continuing on a sour note, you need a computer with dedicated graphics and a broadband internet connection to pull this game off. Or else the lag will probably kill it for you. Reflecting on this, anyone who doesn’t have dedicated graphics should probably not be on Steam, although you can play Vindictus without a Steam account.
I haven’t covered everything, because that would take forever, but I feel as I’ve given you enough that you can decide whether or not to give this game a shot. Good luck!

reviewText: Well folks it is that time a year again another sale. So you have the privilege to be humored by another one of my famous game recommendations. Awwwww Vindictus this game starts off with a very Games of Thrones feeling in the sense, that  it is not frowned upon to have an intimate relationship with a giant spider or other monsterous creatures, or as in Game of Thrones with your own family members. Once out of the tutorial you find yourself in a small sea port village which will now forever be your home. This town is similar to Animal Farm in the sense that animals for the most part run the economy of the game. Gentleman if you invite your lady friend to join you on this epic journey that is Vindictus keep an eye out for the pigs, because they are the womanizers and will steal your lady right from you! ALSO THINK OF A COOL MOTTO. If you don't have one don't play, because you need to start off each new quest/adventure with a laugh and if you can't provide that, then stick to solitaire!

reviewText: Vindictus is a game sort of like Warframe if you've played the game, you would already know the feel of a third person action RPG. While Warframe is set in the future, Vindictus is set in medieval times. It has a varierty of characters for different people with different tastes, there's a tank named Karok who can protect his team and also has a decent amount of burst damage, a mage named Evie who can both do insane damage with a scythe & offensive magic while also helping the team with buffs and revives, then for those who prefer a mix of both defensive and offensive there's Fiona, a wielder of sword and shield who can block the enemy's attacks and send forth her own counter attacks to deal out decent burst damage, then comes Kai, an archer who prefers kiting the enemy rather than going ham who wields both rapidfire Crossbow like gun, and a slower but more hard hitting bow which can be transformed in the middle of combat from a longbow to a shortbow whether you need better fire rate or more range and can find the enemy's weakpoint and use it to temporarily stun them and deal bonus damage. Then there is Lann and Vella, while both wield dual swords, Lann can wield dual spears, while Vella can wield dual Chainblades (the damn thing has HUGE range) and both can offer different skills while still offer speedy gameplay. Finally there is Hurk, the beserker, he focuses on constant AOE while also using skills to attack endlessly, ignore CC, restore health, and if you have good timing, you can even deflect the boss's attacks and counter attack to CC the boss and deal huge damage. Now some of you may be thinking of the community, but don't fret the community is both funny and helpful by helping new players finish missions which would normally be too difficult to overcome. While others may be too lazy to bother leveling up at such a slow pace, do not even worry about it. You'll get into mid game faster than you will think. The only problem I've had with this game is the constant upgrading of gear and finding the right build paths to maximize overall effctiveness throughout the game as well as the rather ludicrous pricing on premium items as well as the 2x exp VIP bonuses. Overall, I've had a lot of fun in this game and I recommend this for anyone who likes RPG's and can deal with a slow start for a faster paced and challenging mid-late game where personal player skills will be tested.

reviewText:
Even though hosted by Nexon, this game is still a must play. The gameplay is almost like no other I have seen in an RPG, and I'm not sure I can really think of a way to explain it very well. It's a real-time RPG with motion controls based on timing, some skill, and extremely enjoyable. The combat ALONE could be a reason to play this game. Not only that, but if you want, there is a port for xbox controllers/etc, so you can play with what you want if mouse and keyboard isn't your preference. It's one of my favorite games. It's pretty easy to get into and get lost in for hours on end.

(I also want to say that I only have low hours on steam, because I played this game from the original launcher before it was on steam.

-NOTE-
As I stated (and as you will see in other reviews), it is a game coming from Nexon. There are bound to be issues found with just that, and there are many bugs, and hackers running amuck. Even though there are hackers, the chance of you being in a  mission with one or even to some extent being hacked yourself, is very low. I don't consider this game pay to win at all, and most of the money you would put into the game would go towards vanity. Of course there are boosters, but as goes with all free to play games, there is almost a guarantee to find some.

Try it out, the only reason I see anyone not atleast enjoying this game some, is if it's not your game style. Even casual" gamers can like this

reviewText:
This game.  It has been out since 2010, I was a closed beta early bird" access member.  I remember browsing mmo sites to the end looking for something that was click to attack and wasn't purely pvp like "rakion" when I had the chance to play it.

The story in this game is fairly decent.  Everything comes together no matter how messed up the timeline may be.
The game is heading in a good direction by trying to attract more players.  I look forward to what is to come.  They finally got their ♥♥♥ in gear and I'm right behind them with a game I can't seem to put down.  I've quit many times over these last four years myself.  I've been through all the phases of the game and if I haven't it means something new is out.  I have tried recruiting all of my friends in real life to come join me because the end game is much friendlier with friends.

The combat system is based around normal attacks and smashes.  Each character as their own unique specials and everyone will eventually have two full weapon styles to play around with.  They are gender locked though.  Each character has their own backstory but everyone goes through the same thing.  Gear progression might not be so forgiving as you will either have to farm for it
date: or pay for it with in-game money.\n\nIf you have spare time. Vindictus is something you should consider yourself playing.  I want to see this game become something it should have already been."

reviewText:
Brutal. Elegant. Over-Powered. Those are the three words I would choose to describe this amazing game. There is nothing more satisfying than grabbing some random object lying around and proceeding to throw down on a room full of baddies with nothing more than a piece of pottery and your winning smile. When you're finished decimating the basic mobs with stone-ware, you can grab your primary weapon and wipe out a wave of middle-management in a flash.

Vindictus is co-developed and published by Valve, Nexon, and Neko. I consider it T for Teen or PEGI 16.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The action is the main thing that makes this game fun and complex. The attacks look as though there is force put in to it, and it shows when they hit an enemy, with a satisfying crunch, thud, or smack.

Other parts that make it good, is the stable player turnover rate, community, look, and hardware inclusivity:

The game has different towns/cities that cater to the different level tiers. This keeps newcomers (and the server) from drowning in a sea of Lv. 50-100 players that have been there since opening day. The game has been slowing down in growth since opening, but such is the life of MMOs. It still has new players joining in, so please don't be too discouraged by the amount of old vs. new players.

Every player I've met through the game is either behaves professionally (which can get annoying for all involved if you just want to kick a Fomor around and they're already at the end of the stage) or they are there to have fun and sometimes you will wind up in a Gnoll-kicking fest that finishes with a new addition to your friend list.

If you didn't look at the trailers, or you just glanced over them, look again. That is how this free game looks. I am not kidding. It looks like that. All the enviroments, be it ruins like the pyramids in The Mummy" or jungles like Skull Island from the newer King Kong film
date: it's there and it's pretty and scary as all get out.\n\nBy hardware inclusivity
recommended: I mean that the settings on this game allow for a fairly wide demographic of players to run the game well. I have played this game on a laptop. It ran on low and fast settings
hoursPlayed: but it ran without lag. I have seen it on high
voteText: where it doesn't play on my laptop. but it looks great. It still looks good
helpfulPercent:
but it's like PS2 high end graphics vs. PS3 high end graphics. There is a difference.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

reviewText: Vindictus is a game that can be both enjoyable and challenging, but can also be tedious and long. The first couple of levels are a cake walk. You start out with the basic skills and equipment and as you further move along the game, you gain more points for skills, random weapon/equipment drops fit for your current level, and in-game money for future spending. This stage of the game is easy and can be finished, solo with little effort. However, as the levels get harder and the bosses get bigger (polar bears to trolls to wolves to dragons to demons), more effort is needed to continue further. Solo is pretty much gone unless you're a high enough level and have high tier equipment. But at this stage, team work and the in-game market come into play. You will need other people to play with to complete the oncoming barrage of difficult levels and the Market in-game is needed to get more powerful and resilient equipment (in-game money used). So if communication and grinding aren't your thing, Vindictus' mid-late and late game will not be for you. However, with enough hard work and dedication, you can be a hulking image in Vindictus with no real life money spent whatsoever. Vindictus trully is a game for the dedicated and skilled.\n\n-Yumi
